affiliations: Department of Public Health and Preventive Medicine, Oregon Health & Science University, Portland, OR, United States
title: Truth telling, placebos, and deception: Ethical and legal issues in practice
doc: <title>Truth telling, placebos, and deception: Ethical and legal issues in practice</title> <excerpt>The issue of truth-telling is very complex. There is variance among patients in the amount of information they want to be told and variance among professionals in the amount of information they want to tell. Truth is conditioned by our knowledge limits and understanding.</excerpt>

affiliations: Calspan Corporation, Buffalo, NY, United States
title: The effects of task performance on ocular accommodation and perceived size
doc: <title>The effects of task performance on ocular accommodation and perceived size</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Aircrew Selection and Classification Research Function, Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States
title: The USAF pilot selection and classification research program
doc: <title>The USAF pilot selection and classification research program</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Air Station, Naval Safety Center, Norfolk, VA, United States
title: Pilot error as a symptom of inadequate stress coping
doc: <title>Pilot error as a symptom of inadequate stress coping</title> <excerpt>Over 700 psychological questionnaires, completed on naval aviators who had been involved in major aircraft mishaps over a 4-year period were divided into two groups. Those collected on aviators who were causally involved in their mishaps were compared with those who had no culpability in their mishaps. Those who were assigned pilot error demonstrated symptoms of having problems with interpersonal relationships, an indication of 'acting out' behavior.</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Army Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Novosel, AL, United States
title: Helicopter copilot workload during nap-of-the-earth flight
doc: <title>Helicopter copilot workload during nap-of-the-earth flight</title> <excerpt>Two automatic navigation systems, a Doppler radar system and a projected map system, and a hand-held map were examined for their effects on copilot/navigator workload and performance. The automatic navigation systems reduced the number of navigation errors and the size of deviations from intended track. The Doppler system reduced the time devoted to navigating and the number of verbal navigation messages exchanged between the pilot and copilot.</excerpt>

affiliations: Flight Skills Section, Royal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, Hampshire, United Kingdom
title: An analysis of crew co-ordination problems in commercial transport aircraft
doc: <title>An analysis of crew co-ordination problems in commercial transport aircraft</title> <excerpt>This paper describes a survey of co-ordination problems and attitudes amongst a sample of 250 commercial airline pilots. The results indicate that co-ordination problems are most likely when the workload is high. Deviation from standard operating procedures was also identified by the pilots as a major source of co-orrdination problems.</excerpt>

affiliations: Kingseat Hospital, Newmachar, United Kingdom
title: The emotional consequences of ejection, rescue and rehabilitation in Royal Air Force aircrew
doc: <title>The emotional consequences of ejection, rescue and rehabilitation in Royal Air Force aircrew</title> <excerpt>Retrospective questionnaire information was sought from 175 Royal Air Force officers who had survived ejection from an aircraft and 88% replied. A profile of risk factors, both objective and subjective, was found in the 40% who subsequently experienced prolonged emotional disturbances. Confidential counselling of ejection survivors should therefore be routine.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aeronautical Human Factors Research Office, NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: Circadian rhythmicity and fatigue in flight operations
doc: <title>Circadian rhythmicity and fatigue in flight operations</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Sociology, Kwansei Gakuin University, Nishinomiya, Hyogo, Japan
title: Cognitive problems in aviation psychological studies
doc: <title>Cognitive problems in aviation psychological studies</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aviation Authority, London, Engl, United Kingdom
title: Aviation safety - physical and mental incapacitation
doc: <title>Aviation safety - physical and mental incapacitation</title> <excerpt>There is a trend of continual improvement in flight safety and the best airlines flying the best aircraft are now achieving fatal accident rates of less than one in one million flying hours or flights. In this paper an overview is presented of the relationship of pilot age, physical incapacitation and mental disorders to accidents..</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Physical Education, Yarmouk University, Irbid, Irbid, Jordan
title: Personality and somatotype of trainee pilots
doc: <title>Personality and somatotype of trainee pilots</title> <excerpt>Personality and somatotype studies of pilots have mostly been restricted to military pilots and experienced airline crews. In this investigation of 16 PF and Heath-Carter somatotype method were utilized to study 31 male aviation majors, aged between 18 and 38 yr., who had earned their Private Pilots Licenses and were working toward more advanced ratings. The pilots varied significantly from the male college student norm on Factors E, F, G, H, and Q3 of the 16 PF.</excerpt>

title: The American Institutes for Research
doc: <title>The American Institutes for Research</title> <excerpt>Reviews the development, research approaches, and focus of the American Institutes for Research, which was an outgrowth from the success of the Aviation Psychology Program in the US Army Air Forces in World War II. The organization was incorporated as a nonprofit agency to carry out research on problems for government, education, and industry. Areas of research and interest include criteria for successful job performance, development of guidance batteries, revision of traditional educational objectives, the modification of tasks to improve effectiveness and safety, and the selection and training of leaders.</excerpt>

affiliations: College of Engineering, Columbus, OH, United States
title: Computer-aided testing of pilot response to critical in-flight events
doc: <title>Computer-aided testing of pilot response to critical in-flight events</title> <excerpt>This research on pilot response to critical in-flight events employs a unique methodology including an interactive computer-aided scenario-testing system. Navigation displays, instrument-panel displays, and assorted textual material are presented on a touch-sensitive CRT screen. Problem diagnosis scenarios, destination-diversion scenarios and combined destination/diagnostic tests are available.</excerpt>

affiliations: Canadian Air Transportation Administration, Ottawa, ON, Canada
title: An investigation of the effectiveness of pilot judgment training
doc: <title>An investigation of the effectiveness of pilot judgment training</title> <excerpt>Pilot decisional errors have always been a significant factor in aviation accidents. Pilot judgment, however, traditionally has been viewed as an intrinsic quality or a by-product of flying experience. Only recently has it been examined as a potential flight-training requirement.</excerpt>

affiliations: Essex Corporation, Westlake Village, CA, United States
title: Application of a multifactor approach to transfer of training research
doc: <title>Application of a multifactor approach to transfer of training research</title> <excerpt>A multifactor, multicriterion transfer of training experiment involving a computer-generated horizontal tracking task was conducted to establish relationships among training and transfer scores for manual control of a maneuvering vehicle, to determine the response surfaces for training and transfer, and to demonstrate a new transfer research paradigm that makes economically feasible the simultaneous investigation of the effects of a large number of training-equipment and use variables on transfer to multiple-criterion vehicle configurations. There were 80 experimental participants, 48 of whom were trained and tested on individually unique combinations of training and transfer conditions. This study measures the training and transfer effects of as many as six training equipment and use factors in a single experiment, to examine as many as 25 training-vehicle configurations in the same experiment, to train a single individual on each of 48 training conditions, to employ multiple (3) transfer vehicle configurations, and to provide data suitable for deriving multiple-regression equations for estimating the transfer effectiveness of configurations not directly studied.; A multifactor, multicriterion transfer of training experiment involving a computer-generated horizontal tracking task was conducted to establish relationships among training and transfer scores for manual control of a maneuvering vehicle, to determine the response surfaces for training and transfer, and to demonstrate a new transfer research paradigm that makes economically feasible the simultaneous investigation of the effects of a large number of training-equipment and use variables on transfer to multiple-criterion vehicle configurations.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States
title: Cockpit management attitudes
doc: <title>Cockpit management attitudes</title> <excerpt>Distinctions are drawn between personality traits and attitudes. The stability of the personality and the malleability of attitudes are stressed. These concepts are related to pilot performance, especially in the areas of crew coordination and cockpit resource management.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Massachusetts Amherst, Amherst, MA, United States
title: A brief history of aviation psychology
doc: <title>A brief history of aviation psychology</title> <excerpt>This paper presents an overview of the field of aviation psychology from its pre-World War I beginnings to current problems and opportunities for today's aviation psychologists. This brief survey covers some of the more significant early activities of aviation psychologists in the United States and Europe..</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: Principles of S-C-R compatibility with spatial and verbal tasks: The role of display-control location and voice-interactive display-control interfacing
doc: <title>Principles of S-C-R compatibility with spatial and verbal tasks: The role of display-control location and voice-interactive display-control interfacing</title> <excerpt>A pilot's tasks may be categorized into those that demand predominantly verbal operations and those that are spatial. We describe two experiments that define two principles of compatibility of interfacing such tasks with displays and controls. The first, based upon hemispheric laterality effects, defines compatibility according to the display location and the response hand; the second defines compatibility according to the modality of display (auditory and visual) and response (manual and speech).</excerpt>

affiliations: NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: Dyads and triads at 35,000 feet: Factors affecting group process and aircrew performance
doc: <title>Dyads and triads at 35,000 feet: Factors affecting group process and aircrew performance</title> <excerpt>Discusses the small-group performance situation involved in the task of flying a multipilot transport aircraft and research psychology's problems in defining the nature of the group process. Input variables (eg, task characteristics, reward structure, position power, stress levels) have been identified and related to the flightcrew process. There have been suggestions that leader and member personality profiles are important predictors of group process variables in the aviation environment.</excerpt>

affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Washington, D.C., DC, United States
title: NASA's life sciences and space radiation biology
doc: <title>NASA's life sciences and space radiation biology</title> <excerpt>Plans for the various missions in which men and women are expected to participate during the next 10 years are outlined. Such missions include flights of up to three months duration in low earth orbit as well as possible short excursions to geosynchronous orbit. Research activities are described which cover the full spectrum of physiological and psychological responses to space flight.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Physiology, The University of Manchester, Manchester, Greater Manchester, United Kingdom
title: The use of constant routines in unmasking the endogenous component of human circadian rhythms
doc: <title>The use of constant routines in unmasking the endogenous component of human circadian rhythms</title> <excerpt>A major problem in the study of the internal clock(s) that drives human circadian rhythms is that due to the effect produced by rhythmicity of habits and external influences ("masking" A particularly potent factor in this respect is the sleep-wake cycle. It is anomalous that, even though this masking influence is widely accepted, most studies of circadian rhythmicity have been performed in the presence of such interferences. A protocol is described, the constant routine, by which these exogenous influences can be minimized, thereby enabling a closer scrutiny of the internal clock(s) to be made.</excerpt>

affiliations: Center for Health Studies, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
title: The politics of stress: The case of air traffic control
doc: <title>The politics of stress: The case of air traffic control</title> <excerpt>Analysis of the 1981 Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization strike suggests that workers who employ the concept of stress to describe undesirable job conditions risk unexpected negative consequences. In deciding not to make subjective claims that can only be addressed in political terms, workers necessarily appeal to outside experts to provide scientific, objective descriptions of job conditions. Unfortunately, different experts define stress in strikingly different ways, allowing for a kind of shell game in which the very existence of stress can become problematical.</excerpt>

affiliations: Human Factors Group Vehicle Simulation Laboratory, Virginia Tech College of Engineering, Blacksburg, VA, United States
title: On the measurement of pilot perceptual workload: A comparison of assessment techniques addressing sensitivity and intrusion issues
doc: <title>On the measurement of pilot perceptual workload: A comparison of assessment techniques addressing sensitivity and intrusion issues</title> <excerpt>A flight simulator-based study was conducted to examine fourteen distinct mental workload estimation measures, including opinion, secondary task, physiological, and primary task measures. Both the relative sensitivity of the measures to changes in mental workload and the differential intrusion of the changes on primary task performance were assessed. The flight task was varied in difficulty by manipulation of the presentation rate and complexity of a hazard-perception task that required each of 48 licensed pilots to rely heavily on their perceptual abilities.</excerpt>

affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA, United States
title: Synthesized warning messages: effects of an alerting cue in single- and multiple-function voice synthesis systems
doc: <title>Synthesized warning messages: effects of an alerting cue in single- and multiple-function voice synthesis systems</title> <excerpt>The present study examined the effectiveness of preceding synthesized voice warning messages with an alerting cue as a function of the amount of information presented by the voice synthesizer and the workload level in the primary task. Subjects performed a simplified air traffic control task in which they were required to monitor two visual displays and to enter commands via a standard keyboard. Emergency messages were always presented by phoneme-based synthesized speech.</excerpt>

affiliations: NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: Perceived threat and avoidance maneuvers in response to cockpit traffic displays
doc: <title>Perceived threat and avoidance maneuvers in response to cockpit traffic displays</title> <excerpt>Airline pilots rated their perception of the danger of an air-to-air collision based on cockpit displays of traffic information while they monitored simulated departures. They selected avoidance maneuvers when necessary for separation. Most evasive maneuvers were turns rather than vertical maneuvers.</excerpt>

title: The use of relaxation/desensitization in treating anxiety associated with flying
doc: <title>The use of relaxation/desensitization in treating anxiety associated with flying</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

title: Heart rate variability, cardiac mechanics, and subjectively evaluated stress during simulator flight
doc: <title>Heart rate variability, cardiac mechanics, and subjectively evaluated stress during simulator flight</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA, United States
title: A comparison of rating scale, secondary-task, physiological, and primary-task workload estimation techniques in a simulated flight task emphasizing communication load
doc: <title>A comparison of rating scale, secondary-task, physiological, and primary-task workload estimation techniques in a simulated flight task emphasizing communication load</title> <excerpt>Sixteen potential metrics of pilot mental workload were investigated regarding their sensitivity to communication load and their intrusion on primary-task performance. A moving-base flight simulator was used to present three cross-country flights. The flights varied only in the difficulty of the communications requirements.</excerpt>

affiliations: Faculty of Education, The University of Newcastle, Australia, Callaghan, NSW, Australia
title: Personality profiles of pilots
doc: <title>Personality profiles of pilots</title> <excerpt>Samples of Air Force fighter pilots, trainee commercial pilots, and males drawn from the general community completed the Edwards Personality Preference Schedule (EPPS). Four significant effects were found for individual sub-scales; three (Achievement, Affiliation, and Nurturance) identifying air force fighter pilots. Commercial pilot trainees scored significantly less than the community sample on Succorance and Nurturance.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychiatry, Eastern Virginia Medical School, Norfolk, VA, United States
title: Isolated sleep paralysis after rapid time zone change ('jet lag') syndrome
doc: <title>Isolated sleep paralysis after rapid time zone change ('jet lag') syndrome</title> <excerpt>Isolated sleep paralysis is the sudden inability to perform voluntary movements occurring at the onset of sleep or upon awakening during the night or in the morning. Consciousness remains clear, although dreamlike states of hallucinations may occur during the episode of paralysis. An attack ususally lasts 10 min or less and ends spontaneously through external sensory stimulation, or by the intense efforts of the patient.</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiat. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: The evolution and present status of mental health standards for selection of USAF candidates for space missions
doc: <title>The evolution and present status of mental health standards for selection of USAF candidates for space missions</title> <excerpt>The mental health evaluation of the original Mercury astronauts was a prolonged, meticulous, research-oriented process involving testing and interviews to determine who was best qualified for space flight. The trend since then has been to simplify this evaluation, making it more subjective and clinically oriented. The goal is to identify candidates who are fully qualified, free of psychopathology, and who have a healthy motivation for space flight.</excerpt>

affiliations: R. Air Force, London, United Kingdom
title: Psychiatric illness in military aircrew
doc: <title>Psychiatric illness in military aircrew</title> <excerpt>The selection and assessment of military aircrew depends on accurate information, which should be obtained not only from the pilot but also from his peers and his employer. Psychological reactions are related to interactions between the man, his task, and his environment, both service and personal. The value of an arousal system in response to stress is discussed together with the physical and psychological symptoms of anxiety..</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aviation Authority, London, United Kingdom
title: Psychiatric disorders in civilian pilots
doc: <title>Psychiatric disorders in civilian pilots</title> <excerpt>Psychiatric disorders are second only to cardiovascular disorders as a cause of permanent loss of licence in both professional aircrew and private pilots in the UK. In professional aircrew, psychiatric disorders are commonly aviation-related, whilst in private pilots less effective selection and the stresses of business and personal affairs are common factors. Because human error is a major cause of accidents, the early diagnosis of disorders of thought and behaviour is clearly crucial in promoting flight safety.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Community Medicine, Wright State University, Dayton, OH, United States
title: The human element in air traffic control: Aeromedical aspects, problems, and prescriptions
doc: <title>The human element in air traffic control: Aeromedical aspects, problems, and prescriptions</title> <excerpt>During periods of reduced visibility, air traffic controllers are the most critical factor in aircraft collision avoidance. Controllers also largely determine efficiency in the mass movement of aircraft on instrument plans. Individual and group controller health and well-being are essential to the sustained efficient and safe operation of these aircraft in the National Airspace System.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of California, Irvine, Irvine, CA, United States; Indiana University Bloomington, Bloomington, IN, United States; University of California, Irvine, Irvine, CA, United States
title: Assaults in the air: Concerning attacks against flight attendants
doc: <title>Assaults in the air: Concerning attacks against flight attendants</title> <excerpt>Violence directed at airline personnel by passengers while an aircraft is in flight presents an interesting and uncommon form of deviant behavior that can inform the study of deviance in general. Such behavior has been identified by various observers as a growing social problem. This paper explores the phenomenon of assaults against flight attendants through analysis of official data including both case files and statistics, interviews with officials, and a multidisciplinary literature review.</excerpt>

affiliations: Trondheinm School of Social Work, Norway; Norges Teknisk-Naturvitenskapelige Universitet, Trondheim, Trondelag, Norway; Uppsala Universitet, Uppsala, Uppsala, Sweden
title: Anxiety and Coping Behavior During an Emergency Landing
doc: <title>Anxiety and Coping Behavior During an Emergency Landing</title> <excerpt>A flight from London to New York (the Titanic itinerary), presenting a flight crash on one of the screens and a film about the Titanic on the other, suddenly had a fire on board. The captain intended to make an emergency landing on the water near the spot where the Titanic disappeared. The level of anxiety was high among passengers and even more so among the cabin crew members.</excerpt>

title: Ait travel fatigue
doc: <title>Ait travel fatigue</title> <excerpt>Travel fatigue is a condition both acute and chronic, which occurs in the travelling public and also affects pilots and cabin crew. Much can be done to alleviate this condition, by modification of flight schedules and conditions during flight. More can be done by promoting a better understanding between management, operations staff and aviation medical personnel familiar with airline operations..</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, University College London, London, United Kingdom
title: Predicting performance in aircrew
doc: <title>Predicting performance in aircrew</title> <excerpt>There can be little doubt that human error is a major causal factor in flying (and, indeed, other) accidents. This is particularly likely to be so in flying modern fighter aircraft. Detecting in advance to likely response of pilots to the stress associated with such a task may prevent a number of disasters.</excerpt>

title: HABITABILITY SUPPORT FOR MANNED MISSIONS OF SPACE 2000.
doc: <title>HABITABILITY SUPPORT FOR MANNED MISSIONS OF SPACE 2000.</title> <excerpt>This paper presents the concept of a habitability support subsystem consisting of those design elements needed to satisfy the psychological and social needs of the flight crews of advanced missions. Utilizing such a concept in the design of space vehicles will serve to emphasize and focus attention on spacecraft design features which in the past have been subservient to the more visible aspects of environmental control and life support. This paper further identifies the needs for crew habitability in the manned missions of the future, identifies the technology available today, and describes the technological activities needed in the coming decades to prepare for Space 2000..</excerpt>

affiliations: Sapienza Università di Roma, Rome, RM, Italy
title: Biofeedback monitoring-devices for astronauts in space environment
doc: <title>Biofeedback monitoring-devices for astronauts in space environment</title> <excerpt>After a reconsideration of the state-of-the-art in biofeedback research the implementation of biofeedback systems is envisioned as a countermeasure of stress for the psychoprophylaxis of the astronaut. A one-session experiment performed on two groups of subjects to assess the interference from EMG-feedback on the performance in a simultaneous psychomotor trial with a view to expanding biofeedback application is described. The results show that the experimental group performed in the same way as the control without feedback, but with less CNS activation.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Safety Center, Norfolk, VA, United States
title: Flight experience and naval aircraft mishaps
doc: <title>Flight experience and naval aircraft mishaps</title> <excerpt>Naval aircraft mishaps involving pilot error for a 5-yr period were analyzed to determine the specific underlying causes as functions of lifetime and recent experience. The data show that certain problems tend to manifest themselves at different levels of experience. Moreover, the potential for a mishap itself is correlated with these experience levels..</excerpt>

affiliations: Dept. of Prev. Med. and Biometrics, Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Bethesda, MD, United States
title: Psychological well-being in united states air force fliers
doc: <title>Psychological well-being in united states air force fliers</title> <excerpt>Three dimensions of overall health are defined by the World Health Organization-physical, mental, and social. Psychological well-being has been a popular research topic recently and has been shown to relate to mental health. The analysis of distinct population groups offers unique opportunities for the investigation of the interplay of the psychological, social, and physical elements of health.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychiatry, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, WI, United States
title: The journey out and in: Psychiatry and space exploration
doc: <title>The journey out and in: Psychiatry and space exploration</title> <excerpt>Although psychiatric issues have in theory always been considered important in space biomedical research, specific research into these issues has been severely limited because of other priorities that were more pertinent to the technological development of space flight capacity. As the technical and physical aspects of space flight become more routine, the psychological issues should take on increasing importance. The author reviews the U.S.</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aeromedical Institute, FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Cardiorespiratory assessment of 24-hour crash-diet effects on altitude, +Gz, and fatigue tolerances
doc: <title>Cardiorespiratory assessment of 24-hour crash-diet effects on altitude, +Gz, and fatigue tolerances</title> <excerpt>Eleven male surrogates of general aviation pilots, 21-35 years old, were tested for altitude, +Gz, and fatigue tolerances with and without previous fasting for 24 hr. Testing included 2 min of lower body negative pressure (LBNP) at-40 torr (equivalent to +2Gz) after 118 min at 3,810 m chamber altitude and, after returning to ground level pressure, ergometry of 50 watts (W) for 6 min. The fast had no statistically significant effect on altitude and fatigue tolerances.</excerpt>

affiliations: England AFB, LA, United States
title: Negative transfer: A threat to flying safety
doc: <title>Negative transfer: A threat to flying safety</title> <excerpt>Negative transfer is defined in the context of this paper as the transfer from one cockpit to another - of different design or configuration - of habits or responses which were appropriate in the former but are inappropriate in the latter, thereby posing a threat to flying safety. This danger has been demonstrated not only experimentally but also in a number of aircraft accident investigation reports. As new aircraft become available to the commercial, military, and private sectors and pilots consequently must transition from older to newer models, the phenomenon of negative transfer becomes increasingly significant.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Amherst, MA, United States
title: Validation of a proposed pilot-trainee selection system
doc: <title>Validation of a proposed pilot-trainee selection system</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Behavioral Engineering Laboratory, New Mexico State University, Las Cruces, NM, United States
title: Landing airplanes, detecting traffic, and the dark focus
doc: <title>Landing airplanes, detecting traffic, and the dark focus</title> <excerpt>Misjudgements of position in flight and failures to detect other airbone traffic are casualties of the eternal tug-of-war between visible texture and the pilot's dark focus. The eye is lazy and resists the pull of a distant stimulus, preferring to rest at relatively short focal distance, as it does in the dark or when looking at the sky. Judgements of apparent size are highly correlated with visual accomodation distance, and the difficulty of detecting airplanes on stationary collision courses is greatly aggravated when focus is trapped by structures close to the eyes.</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: III.
doc: <title>Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: III.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Aviation Research Laboratory, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: An adaptive private pilot certification exam
doc: <title>An adaptive private pilot certification exam</title> <excerpt>Adapting aviation certification exams to each examinee's ability may reduce administration costs and increase the accuracy of certification decisions. Several means of adapting exams are based upon item response theory. Item response theory allows one to empirically describe a test item very precisely before it is administered.</excerpt>

affiliations: Flight Med. Branch Clin. Sci. Div., U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Motivational analysis of human volunteers for centrifuge acceleration research
doc: <title>Motivational analysis of human volunteers for centrifuge acceleration research</title> <excerpt>Motivational analysis of a representative group of individuals who volunteer to participate in centrifuge acceleration research at the USAF School of Aerospace Medicine was performed. Monetary reward and curiosity were the main reasons for volunteering to participate in the research program. Fear and monetary reward not worth the risk were the main reasons for not volunteering to participate.</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: The influence of differential physical conditioning regimens on simulated aerial combat maneuvering tolerance
doc: <title>The influence of differential physical conditioning regimens on simulated aerial combat maneuvering tolerance</title> <excerpt>The influence of physical conditioning on tolerance to a centrifugation profile called the Simulated Aerial Combat Maneuvering (SACM) was determined using 24 young men as subjects. These subjects were assigned to groups as controls (no physical training, C), runners (R), and weight trainers (W). They followed a 12-week protocol of specified physical training.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aerospace Medicine, Wright State University, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Circadian rhythms and fatigue: A discrimination of their effects on performance
doc: <title>Circadian rhythms and fatigue: A discrimination of their effects on performance</title> <excerpt>Different effects between circadian rhythms and fatigue have been discriminated. The discrimination was based on human performance changes. It was shown that such changes, not related to loss of sleep, are more easily attributable to either circadian rhythm or fatigue effects.</excerpt>

affiliations: NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: The role of communications, socio-psychological, and personality factors in the maintenance of crew coordination
doc: <title>The role of communications, socio-psychological, and personality factors in the maintenance of crew coordination</title> <excerpt>There is increasing evidence that many air transport incidents and accidents are the result of the improper or inadequate utilization of the resources accessible to flight deck crew members. These resources obviously include the hardware and technical information necessary for the safe and efficient conduct of the flight, but they also include the human resources which must be coordinated effectively. The focus of this paper is upon the human resources, and how communication styles, socio-psychological factors, and personality characteristics can affect crew coordination..</excerpt>

affiliations: MITRE Corporation, McLean, VA, United States
title: A study of decision-making behavior of aircraft pilots deviating from a planned flight
doc: <title>A study of decision-making behavior of aircraft pilots deviating from a planned flight</title> <excerpt>This paper outlines an investigation into the worth structures of pilots facing a deviation from a planned flight. A 'paper and pencil' simulation was used to frame the situation into which pilots interjected their own decision-making skills in a simple ranking of candidate diversion airports with varying locational, navigational aid, radar, and weather attributes. Using the conjoint measurement technique, attribute worth functions of 30 pilots were constructed.</excerpt>

affiliations: Dep of Industrial Engineering, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Amherst, MA, United States
title: Sex as a moderator variable in the selection and training of persons for a skilled task
doc: <title>Sex as a moderator variable in the selection and training of persons for a skilled task</title> <excerpt>We gave 51 male and 52 female Air Force Academy Cadets a battery of five cognitive and three perceptual motor tests before they were taught four basic flight maneuvers followed by a complex chandelle maneuver. The results showed that the males were much faster in attaining the criterion level of performance on the flight tasks, and that some of the sex differences in the acquisition of task skills can be reduced by means of pretraining on specific cognitive and motor skills. In the prediction of trials to criterion (acquisition rate) of both the basic and the complex flight maneuvers, individually tailoring the regression equations by sex - as opposed to utilizing general overall regression equations - greatly enhanced the predictive capability..</excerpt>

affiliations: Logicon Inc., Torrance, CA, United States
title: Instructional design for aircrew judgement training
doc: <title>Instructional design for aircrew judgement training</title> <excerpt>Aircrew training design has made significant progress during recent years. However, significant gaps exist both in design methodology and in existing skills. Training in decision-making and judgement is currently haphazard at best.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States
title: Functional optical invariants: A new methodology for aviation research
doc: <title>Functional optical invariants: A new methodology for aviation research</title> <excerpt>The application to aviation physiology of Gibson's 'ecological approach to visual perception' demands information-rich visual displays to adequately and unambiguously enable a pilot to perform flight maneuvers. Optical information often takes the form of invariant properties of a changing optic array, and functional invariants are defined as psychologically effective optical invariants. Their effectiveness is determined by empirical test, but standard experimental paradigms are shown to be inappropriate for testing the effectiveness of information-rich displays.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aviation Research Laboratory, Univ. of Illinois-Willard Airport, IL, United States
title: Towards an internal model in pilot training
doc: <title>Towards an internal model in pilot training</title> <excerpt>Optimal decision making requires an information seeking behavior which reflects the comprehension of the overall system dynamics. Research in the area of human monitors in man-machine systems supports the notion of an internal model with built-in experiences. It is doubtful that the current approach to pilot training helps develop this internal model in the most efficient way.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Mathematical Sciences, United States Air Force Academy, Colorado Springs, CO, United States
title: An analysis of aircrew procedural compliance
doc: <title>An analysis of aircrew procedural compliance</title> <excerpt>This research examines the relationships between aircrew compliance with procedures and operator errors. The data for this analysis were generated by reexamination of a 1976 experiment in full-mission simulation. The character of individual operators, the chemistry of crew composition, and complex aspects of the operational environment affected procedural compliance by crew members.</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiat. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Emotional reactions to military aircraft accidents
doc: <title>Emotional reactions to military aircraft accidents</title> <excerpt>The author has had extensive experience responding to inflight emergencies and actual aircraft accidents, generally of fighter aircraft. This article considers the emotional effects of these events on family members within the squadron, on other squadron aircrew and their families, and on rescue and recovery personnel, and discusses successful coping mechanisms for such stressful situations..</excerpt>

title: Mental stress causes accidents, too.
doc: <title>Mental stress causes accidents, too.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I.
doc: <title>Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Ergonomics Research Group, University of Hull, Hull, East Yorkshire, United Kingdom
title: The Eysenck Personality Inventory as a selection test for military pilots
doc: <title>The Eysenck Personality Inventory as a selection test for military pilots</title> <excerpt>As part of a study of the selection of candidates for pilot training in the Army Air Corps, EPI scores have been analysed in relation to success in training. Data from 432 AAC and 205 RAF student pilots have been examined. Statistical analyses show that EPI scores are related to success in training.</excerpt>

affiliations: R.A.F. Institute of Aviation Medicine, Farnborough, England, United Kingdom
title: Ergonomic aspects of aircraft keyboard design: The effects of gloves and sensory feedback on keying performance
doc: <title>Ergonomic aspects of aircraft keyboard design: The effects of gloves and sensory feedback on keying performance</title> <excerpt>Increasing requirements for aircraft keyboards have indicated inadequacies in ergonomic standards for airborne environments, in particular for tasks involving unskilled, discontinuous data entry, with emphasis on accuracy rather than speed. Four experiments are reported from a programme of research aimed at the development and application of methodologies for assessing factors relevant to keyboard design. Experiment 1 demonstrated that the effects of various aircrew gloves on a representative aircraft data entry task are highly situation specific.</excerpt>

affiliations: San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
title: Conditioned feeding suppression in rats produced by cross-coupled and simple motions
doc: <title>Conditioned feeding suppression in rats produced by cross-coupled and simple motions</title> <excerpt>Conditioned feeding suppression was produced in rats by earth-vertical rotation, seesaw acceleration, and cross-coupled accelerations. Rats were exposed to 15 min of motion immediately after eating a sweet, novel food. The effects of this motion were assessed by measuring consumption of sweet food during a second feeding session that was 72 hr after exposure to motion.</excerpt>

affiliations: Faculty of Administration, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada
title: Recent life change measurement in Canadian forces pilots
doc: <title>Recent life change measurement in Canadian forces pilots</title> <excerpt>This study is the first in a series of steps aimed at developing a management tool that will provide a technique for screening accident-prone aviators. Because 'life change' is found to be a contributing factor to stress and development of illness in both civilian and military populations, the study of life change events in aviators is a reasonable point from which to begin. The Holmes and Rahe Recent Life Change Questionnaire was administered to an experimental group of 158 aviators and two control groups: one group of 127 ground crew who were matched for age and location, and a group of 46 who were matched for rank.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychiatry, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, United States
title: Syncope in aircrew
doc: <title>Syncope in aircrew</title> <excerpt>In a study of 47 aviator patients consecutively referred to U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine for evaluation of alteration of consciousness, 34 cases of syncope were identified. Mechanisms of etiology included 24 vasovagal syncope, 4 with mictriton syncope, and 6 with miscellaneous causes.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Canada, Montreal, QC, Canada
title: Airline pilot disability: Economic impact of an airline preventive medicine program
doc: <title>Airline pilot disability: Economic impact of an airline preventive medicine program</title> <excerpt>The current economic crisis facing most major United States airlines has forced a close examination of airline-sponsored activities. The effectiveness of one airline's pilot preventive medicine program was estimated by comparing disability experience of its pilots against the experience of a larger population of airline pilots. The preventive medicine program at the studied airline was shown to reduce disability experience by one-third, while saving the airline better than $6 million annually.</excerpt>

affiliations: Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (DLR), Koln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany
title: Relative efficacy of the proposed Space Shuttle antimotion sickness medications
doc: <title>Relative efficacy of the proposed Space Shuttle antimotion sickness medications</title> <excerpt>Space motion sickness has been estimated as affecting between 1 3 and 1 2 of all space flight participants. NASA has at the moment proposed a combination of promethazine and ephedrine ( P E) and one of scopolamine and dextroamphetamine ( S D), both given orally, as well as a transdermally applied scopolamine (TAS), as preventive and ameliorative measures. The reported double-blind study tests the early phase actions and efficacy of the transdermal scopolamine (Transderm ™-V of ALZA Corporation) and compares these in detail to the oral medications.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Aerospace Medical Research Laboratory, Pensacola, FL, United States
title: Some non-auditory correlates of the hearing threshold levels of an aviation noise-exposed population
doc: <title>Some non-auditory correlates of the hearing threshold levels of an aviation noise-exposed population</title> <excerpt>In a retrospective analysis of data collected during the 1963 followup of the NAMRL Thousand Aviator Study, two hearing level groups were identified, normal and impaired, and compared along 33 non-auditory dimensions. It was discovered that these two equally noise-exposed groups could be differentiated according to their smoking history and eye color. That is, the impaired hearing group reported smoking more cigarettes for a greater period of time that did the members of the normal hearing group.</excerpt>

affiliations: Wright State University Boonshoft School of Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Reasons for eliminating the 'age 60' regulation for airline pilots
doc: <title>Reasons for eliminating the 'age 60' regulation for airline pilots</title> <excerpt>The calendar age of 60 is no longer medically justifiable as an upper age limit for airline pilots. Advances in gerontologic studies, clinical medicine, and operational flight proficiency evaluations, now allow individual pilot assessments for health status and performance capability. Individualizing the career duration of pilots by eliminating the present age 60 upper limitation will enhance flight safety and efficiency as the highly qualified, experienced, and proficient older healthy pilots continue their productive careers..</excerpt>

title: Air controller strike spotlights job stress.
doc: <title>Air controller strike spotlights job stress.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

title: Soviet space stress.
doc: <title>Soviet space stress.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

title: Italy's contribution, from a medical standpoint, to the space safety of payload scientists, and perspectives for the future.
doc: <title>Italy's contribution, from a medical standpoint, to the space safety of payload scientists, and perspectives for the future.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Evaluation of a manikin psychomotor task
doc: <title>Evaluation of a manikin psychomotor task</title> <excerpt>A small, self-contained microprocessor displays a manikin on a TV screen in various orientations. Subjects are required to choose lateralities depending on a shape also presented on the display, and performance (accuracy and reaction time) is automatically recorded. This task has been evaluated at the USAF school of Aerospace Medicine.</excerpt>

affiliations: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health, Toronto, ON, Canada
title: The psychosocial impact of a labour dispute
doc: <title>The psychosocial impact of a labour dispute</title> <excerpt>As a by‐product of a larger investigation, this paper examines the psychosocial impact of a 1976 labour dispute among Canadian air traffic controllers. Questionnaires were administered to the controllers during the dispute and during two subsequent periods of routine operations, four and 10 months later. The level of distress, as measured by the 30‐item General Health Questionnaire, was significantly higher during the dispute than during routine operations.</excerpt>

affiliations: California State University, Northridge, Northridge, CA, United States
title: Sociological aspects of permanent manned occupancy of space.
doc: <title>Sociological aspects of permanent manned occupancy of space.</title> <excerpt>The author examines human experiences with isolation and confined groups to determine the sociological aspects of social isolation in space. Precedent experiences include Antarctic stations, oceanographic research vessels, submarines, undersea laboratories, and space simulators. The Soviet experience with multiple-person crews on the Salyut 6 space station is explored.</excerpt>

affiliations: INRIA Institut National de Recherche en Informatique et en Automatique, Le Chesnay, Ile-de-France, France
title: Application of signal detection theory to decision making in supervisory control the effect of the operators experience
doc: <title>Application of signal detection theory to decision making in supervisory control the effect of the operators experience</title> <excerpt>Signal detection theory (SDT) was used as a model for a supervisory activity: The decisions of the air-traffic controller using radar. Of particular interest was the 'professional-experience factor which was studied by comparing the performance of trainee and experienced controllers. Through a distinction allowed by SOT between information processing and the decision process (13), it was shown that trainees discriminate better than experienced controllers, but that the latter manifest a greater degree of caution.</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiat. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Biofeedback rehabilitation of airsick aircrew
doc: <title>Biofeedback rehabilitation of airsick aircrew</title> <excerpt>The biofeedback treatment of 20 aircrew, disabled by chronic severe airsickness, is reported. The USAF School of Aerospace Medicine (SAM) Airsick Rehabilitation Program requires careful selection to insure high motivation and thorough medical screening to rule out intercurrent medically disqualifying conditions. Patients are trained in relaxation techniques and placed in a modified Barany chair, capable of tilting as well as rotating.</excerpt>

affiliations: Ment. Hyg. Clin., VA Nebraska Western Iowa Health Care System Omaha Division, Omaha, NE, United States
title: The physician's determination of personnel reliability in sensitive occupations
doc: <title>The physician's determination of personnel reliability in sensitive occupations</title> <excerpt>The Air Force Medical Officer through AFR 35-99 (Personnel Reliability Program) is responsible for the medical evaluation, psychological assessment, and surveillance of persons who will work in sensitive occupations. This paper addresses various personality factors which indicate poor personnel reliability and suggest an interviewing technique of open-ended questions and developmental history assessment to help determine reliability. Once a person is selected into a Personnel Reliability Program, the physician must be alert to the importance of social stress on personnel reliability and performance..</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Nursing peer review: A survey of flight nurse section members
doc: <title>Nursing peer review: A survey of flight nurse section members</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: A computerized repository system for collection and retrieval of acceleration stress research data
doc: <title>A computerized repository system for collection and retrieval of acceleration stress research data</title> <excerpt>A data repository system for use in aeromedical acceleration research has been developed and is currently in use at the USAF School of Aerospace Medicine. The major functions of the repository include: a) increasing safety in human acceleration experimentation, b) documentation of clinical aeromedical evaluations, c) interface with management utilization systems, and d) rapid retrieval of data for analysis to enable a more in-depth understanding of +G(z) physiology. The repository utilizes the System 2000 Data Base Management System.</excerpt>

title: Piloting when you 'should' be sleeping: What effects?
doc: <title>Piloting when you 'should' be sleeping: What effects?</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiat. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Psychiatric disability of Air Force fliers
doc: <title>Psychiatric disability of Air Force fliers</title> <excerpt>Case reports of psychiatric disorders in flying personnel tend to be reported in diagnostic clusters. When viewed separately, these reports suggest specific patterns. When looked at collectively, psychiatric disorders in military aviators follow no specific pattern.</excerpt>

affiliations: The University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, Scotland, United Kingdom
title: Identification of features associated with flying phobia in aircrew
doc: <title>Identification of features associated with flying phobia in aircrew</title> <excerpt>The psychological and physiological features of 20 aircrew consecutively referred for treatment of anxiety symptoms when flying were compared with a matched control group of uncomplaining aircrew. There were no significant differences between the two groups on psychometric tests of personality, though there were differences in skin conductance; the phobics had a higher rate of spontaneous fluctuation, and habituated less to a repeated auditory tone. More of the phobic group worried about their wives and acknowledged childhood and other adulthood phobias; more had a family history of an episode perhaps best described as flying trauma.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology of RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation
title: Informational need of emotional stress
doc: <title>Informational need of emotional stress</title> <excerpt>According to the informational theory of emotions[1], emotions in humans depend on the power of some need (motivation) and the estimation by the subject of the probability (possibility) of the need staisfaction (the goal achievement). Low probability of need satisfaction leads to negative emotions, actively minimized by the subject. Increased probability of satisfaction, as compared to earlier forecast, generates positive emotions, which the subject tries to maximize, ie to enhance, to prolong, to repeat.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Physiology, Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz, Mainz, Rheinland-Pfalz, Germany
title: Nausogenic properties of various dynamic and static force environments
doc: <title>Nausogenic properties of various dynamic and static force environments</title> <excerpt>Motion sickness can occur when an accelerating force acting on the human body repeatedly changes amplitude and direction or both. It also can occur without any motion after transfer into a constant force field significantly different from Earth-gravity. Dynamic and static causes of motion sickness can be distinguished accordingly.</excerpt>

affiliations: Human Performance Laboratory, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, United States
title: Catecholamine excretion in A-10 pilots
doc: <title>Catecholamine excretion in A-10 pilots</title> <excerpt>Catecholamine excretion was determined for 15 USAF pilots during surface attack training in the A-10 aircraft. Timed urine samples were used to determine excretion rates of epinephrine and norepinephrine during basal conditions, during five sorties performed in high-realism simulators, and during six actual flights. Catecholamine excretion was significantly elevated (p<0.05) over basal rates during all 11 training sorties; therefore, it was concluded that A-10 conversion and surface attack training results in a significant stress response in the subjects.</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Toward the development of a new aptitude selection test battery for air traffic control specialists
doc: <title>Toward the development of a new aptitude selection test battery for air traffic control specialists</title> <excerpt>In an effort to update and refine the selection battery for air traffic controllers, five experimental tests measuring aptitudes and skills considered important in air traffic work were administered to 1,828 newly selected air traffic control specialist (ATCS) trainees on their first day of training at the FAA Academy in Oklahoma City. The five experimental tests and the five tests presently used by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) for selecting ATCS trainees were employed in an iterative stepwise regression (stepdown procedure). The tests that made a significant contribution in predicting Academy scores were then used to form a composite and the old test battery and the new battery were compared.</excerpt>

title: Stress and adaptation: the interaction of the pilot personality and disease.
doc: <title>Stress and adaptation: the interaction of the pilot personality and disease.</title> <excerpt>This paper provides a descriptive backdrop for the assessment of the pilot in distress. Adaptation and stress are defined as the central paradigms for looking at behavior. Reference is made to works of Selye, Canon, and Holmes and Rahe.</excerpt>

affiliations: Clin. Pathol. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Serum cholesterol levels in selected air force cadets compared with levels in the West Point study
doc: <title>Serum cholesterol levels in selected air force cadets compared with levels in the West Point study</title> <excerpt>In the USAFSAM Cardiovascular Disease Followup Study, the surprising rise in average cholesterol levels in West Point cadets during the 6 years following their entry into the U.S. Military Academy in 1952 implied a significant increase in risk of heart disease in later years. To ascertain whether that pattern of change suggested increased risk is characteristic of cadets at military academies, a similar study on a smaller scale was conducted on U.S.</excerpt>

affiliations: Bur. Accident Invest., National Transportation Safety Board, Washington, D.C., WA, United States
title: Human error in ATC system operations
doc: <title>Human error in ATC system operations</title> <excerpt>Air traffic control (ATC) system errors rarely occur in today's system. ATC-related aircraft accidents are even rarer events. Nevertheless, more than 90% of all the system errors that do occur stem from human mistakes in attention, judgement, and communications by controllers and their supervisors.</excerpt>

affiliations: Baruch College, New York, NY, United States
title: An information-processing interpretation of air traffic control stress
doc: <title>An information-processing interpretation of air traffic control stress</title> <excerpt>The air traffic controller's job is inherently stressful, resulting in a variety of stress-related symptoms and illnesses. Unusually high information-processing demands are placed upon controllers for extended periods of time, so that they often must work close to the limits of their channel capacity. The effort required to process information, maintain continuous concentration, and render timely and reasonable decisions is likely to be very stressful.</excerpt>

affiliations: Roy. AF Inst. Aviat. Med., Farnborough, Hampshire, United Kingdom
title: The measurement of the air traffic controller
doc: <title>The measurement of the air traffic controller</title> <excerpt>Measures of the air traffic controller are reviewed and critically assessed. There are many reasons for measuring the controller, and no measure can yet be treated as either indispensable or useless. Some of the most successful studies have employed many different measures.</excerpt>

title: Occupational stress of intensive care nurses & air traffic controllers: review of related studies.
doc: <title>Occupational stress of intensive care nurses & air traffic controllers: review of related studies.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

title: Occupational psychology through autobiography: John Parry
doc: <title>Occupational psychology through autobiography: John Parry</title> <excerpt>The Journal of Occupational Psychology is publishing a number of invited personal accounts by psychologists who have made their mark on the history of the subject. This contribution is by John Parry, a pioneer in aviation psychology. 1980 The British Psychological Society.</excerpt>

affiliations: Directorate Prev. Med., Ottawa, Canada
title: Investigation of life change as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: A prospectus
doc: <title>Investigation of life change as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: A prospectus</title> <excerpt>The author presents a personal perspective on attempts to reduce aircraft accidents resulting from human failure in the cockpit. The premise is that accidents result from an imbalance between performance ability and performance demand. Advances in decreasing pilot-induced accidents must come from methods that will prevent the stresses that diminish performance ability.</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Laboratory performance during acute alcohol intoxication and hangover
doc: <title>Laboratory performance during acute alcohol intoxication and hangover</title> <excerpt>Eleven private pilots (seven men and four women) were recruited and trained on the Multiple Task Performance Battery (MTPB), static and dynamic tracking of a localizer/glide slope instrument, and use of the Intoxilyzer. Results showed clear deleterious effects of alcohol on the MTPB and the tracking tasks immediately following drinking. During the morning (hangover) tests, scores on the MTPB and on the static and dynamic tracking tasks showed small circadian effects (scores were better) without impairment due to the alcohol.</excerpt>

affiliations: Private practice of psychiatry, Austin, TX, United States
title: Burning Out Versus “Punching Out”
doc: <title>Burning Out Versus “Punching Out”</title> <excerpt>"Burning out" among air traffic controllers is the syndrome of depression, anxiety, fear of a midair collision, insomnia, and inability to function professionally with confidence. Individuals who suffer such reactions are rapidly retired for medical reasons from air traffic control work. Removal from control work generally results in a rapid abatement of the symptoms.</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiatry Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States; Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, United States; Fairchild AFB, WA, United States
title: Self-concept Changes Related to War Captivity
doc: <title>Self-concept Changes Related to War Captivity</title> <excerpt>A questionnaire was mailed to all US Air Force repatriated prisoners of the Vietnam war (POWs) still on active duty, and to matched controls, in the fall of 1976. Results were analyzed to determine long-term consequences of the war imprisonment experience. We hypothesized that individuals experiencing the greatest stress and frustration might believe they gained more psychologically than those less stressed.</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiat. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Psychiatric education in aerospace medicine
doc: <title>Psychiatric education in aerospace medicine</title> <excerpt>In order to facilitate curriculum design for psychiatric education in aerospace medicine, three groups of physicians were surveyed: experienced flight surgeons, student flight surgeons, and psychiatrists trained in aerospace medicine. Two measures were obtained: 1) an assessment of the usefulness of particular psychiatric skills and knowledge in the practice of aerospace medicine, and 2) a rating of the clinician's abilities in these areas. Results support the primary importance of interviewing and diagnostic skills.</excerpt>

affiliations: Royal Aircraft Establishment, Farnborough, Hampshire, United Kingdom
title: Hyperventilation in aircrew: A review
doc: <title>Hyperventilation in aircrew: A review</title> <excerpt>The causes and effects of hyperventilation, relevant to the flight environment, have been reviewed and one case history is presented. Methods of investigating in-flight hyperventilation are discussed..</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Medicine, The Jikei University School of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
title: Frequency analysis of heart rate variability under flight conditions
doc: <title>Frequency analysis of heart rate variability under flight conditions</title> <excerpt>The factors causing heart rate variability (HRV) were investigated under various kinds of workloads and flight conditions. Frequency analysis of heart rate, and cross-correlation analysis with blood pressure and respiration, were performed by using the fast Fourier analyser. Consequently, the main frequency of HRV at rest consisted of 0.1 Hz and 0.25-0.3 Hz.</excerpt>

title: Coping with expanding nursing practice, knowledge, and technology
doc: <title>Coping with expanding nursing practice, knowledge, and technology</title> <excerpt>Nurses utilize transcultural, transactional, systems, primary, and interdisciplinary approaches to physiological and psychosocial components of patient care. Expanded roles, as well as advances in knowledge and technology have prepared nurses for critical, specialized, primary, aerospace, and independent nursing practice. Exciting as they are, nursing's expanded roles and practices frequently contribute to the burnout and distress phenomena increasingly observed in practicing health care professionals.</excerpt>

affiliations: Boston University Chobanian & Avedisian School of Medicine, Boston, MA, United States
title: Psychosocial modifiers of response to stress
doc: <title>Psychosocial modifiers of response to stress</title> <excerpt>The impact of stress upon an organism is far more complex than the simple design of most stress research implies. We offer an expanded model for studying the relation of stressors to pathological outcomes, which takes into account both the adaptive capacity of the organism before the stressor occurs and the defenses marshalled in response to the stressor. The model also distinguishes among the initial responses of alarm, sustained defensive behaviors, and the relatively irreversible end- states which remain after resistance has ended.</excerpt>

affiliations: Neuropsychiat. Branch, U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Student pilots referred to the neuropsychiatry branch, USAFSAM 1968-78: Implications for selection
doc: <title>Student pilots referred to the neuropsychiatry branch, USAFSAM 1968-78: Implications for selection</title> <excerpt>The case records of 76 student aviators referred to the Neuropsychiatry Branch of the USAF School of Aerospace Medicine during the period 1968-78 are reviewed. Demograhic and diagnostic data are provided including source of recruitment, age, marital status, aircraft flown, flying hours, and diagnostic categories. Psychophysiological categories are particularly scrutinized and cameo case histories provided.</excerpt>

affiliations: Behavioral Radiology Laboratories, VA Medical Center, North Chicago, United States
title: Behavioral and psychological effects of microwave radiation
doc: <title>Behavioral and psychological effects of microwave radiation</title> <excerpt>The first category of behavioral reaction to microwaves and other radiofrequency electromagnetic radiations involves responses confirmed in laboratory experiments from which a dose-response picture indicates absence of damaging effects of acute exposures (typically less than 60 minutes) at whole-body energy-dose rates below 3 mW/g. To result in this dose rate, the power density of incident radiation could be as low as 2 to 3 mW/cm2 for a small animal but would be on the order of 15 to 20 mW/cm2 for a human being. The second category treats of behavioral sequelae of indeterminate origin observed during epidemiological studies of industrial and military populations.</excerpt>

affiliations: Applied Psychology Department, Aston University, Birmingham, West Midlands, United Kingdom
title: The man-machine interface
doc: <title>The man-machine interface</title> <excerpt>Deals with the core topic in ergonomics, the interaction of a human with a machine, with emphasis on psychological, and to some extent physiological, issues in the linkage of man to machine. This topic is divided into a discussion of displays and controls. In particular, the design of computer displays and of air traffic controls are dealt with..</excerpt>

title: The early development of aviation medicine in the United States.
doc: <title>The early development of aviation medicine in the United States.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: On the Evaluation of Training Devices
doc: <title>On the Evaluation of Training Devices</title> <excerpt>The theme of the paper is ways of evaluating flight simulators for aircrew training. The transfer of training experiment and the rating method are the two present-day ways of evaluating the worth of a simulator. The transfer experiment requires the trainee to practice in the simulator and then be tested in the parent aircraft to demonstrate the training value of the simulator.</excerpt>

affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, VA, United States
title: Physiological Measures of Aircrew Mental Workload
doc: <title>Physiological Measures of Aircrew Mental Workload</title> <excerpt>Physiological measures of aircrew mental workload were divided into fourteen specific classes. Each class was then summarized in terms of background, applications, and implications for research and implementation. It is concluded that several physiological measures appear promising, but that more research is needed to provide convincing evidence of viability.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; University of Maryland Extension, Madrid, Spain; University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA, United States
title: Short-Term Memory Factors in Ground Controller/Pilot Communication
doc: <title>Short-Term Memory Factors in Ground Controller/Pilot Communication</title> <excerpt>Communication between ground controllers and pilots was simulated in a short-term memory task in order to explore sources of memory errors in the air traffic control system. As expected from prior short-term memory research, two major determinants of error probability were (1) amount of information that the pilot has to process in a given time and (2) retention interval between the time information is transmitted from the controller and the time it is acted on (recalled) by the pilot. Additionally, the manner of encoding numerical information was varied.</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aeromedical Institute, FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Morbidity experience of air traffic control personnel - 1967-77
doc: <title>Morbidity experience of air traffic control personnel - 1967-77</title> <excerpt>The morbidity experience of 28,086 air traffic controllers has been examined from 1967-77 with particular emphasis to the potential effects of job demands on ATC health. The morbidity experience of air traffic controllers does not appear excessive, except for psychoneurotic disorders, compared with the experience of other outside groups studies. Additionally, a lack of association between disease occurrence and occupation is observed in the data correlation disease occurrence with length of service and age.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Science and Technology, The University of Manchester, Manchester, Greater Manchester, United Kingdom
title: Review of stress in air traffic control: its measurement and effects
doc: <title>Review of stress in air traffic control: its measurement and effects</title> <excerpt>A large number of investigations have been conducted into air traffic control stress by researchers from different disciplines. This paper attempts to draw together this work by examining the methodologies and interpretations that have been used. The purpose of this approach is to highlight the research gaps in the area and to emphasize the need for greater interdisciplinary cooperation in the measurement and interpretation of air traffic control stress..</excerpt>

affiliations: Yale-New Haven Psychiatric Hospital, New Haven, CT, United States; U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Vasovagal syncope in aircrew psychosocial aspects
doc: <title>Vasovagal syncope in aircrew psychosocial aspects</title> <excerpt>Twenty-four aircrew members with the diagnosis of vasovagal syncope were compared to 26 controls on variables of personality characteristics, psychosocial antecedents to the onset of their conditions, and hyperventilation experience. The syncope group was found to be younger, slightly less adaptable, and to have significantly more negative feelings about their work. The authors argue that syncope in aircrew should be considered from a psychosocial perspective as well as from a medical-neurological perspective.</excerpt>

title: Sensorial aspects of helicopter operations
doc: <title>Sensorial aspects of helicopter operations</title> <excerpt>As components of physical and psychic workload in the piloting of helicopters, and therefore as possible concurrent pathogenetic factors of operational fatigue in helicopter aircrews, the author examines and analyzes the effects of some sensorial phenomena related to the use of such rotor-powered aircraft. Particularly acoustic and non-acoustic vibrations associated with flying this type of vehicle are discussed as to their action not only on the auditory apparatus, but also on the function of other apparatuses of the central nervous system, with special reference to the effects exerted by vibratory motions on visual function. Another problem taken into consideration is the disorientation that, particularly during helicopter flights, the pilot may experience whenever there is a conflict between his own sensorial evaluations and the information supplied by the instruments.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Medicine, The Jikei University School of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
title: Evaluation method of mental workload under flight conditions
doc: <title>Evaluation method of mental workload under flight conditions</title> <excerpt>In order to analyze the relationship between heart rate variability (HRV) and the flight tasks of pilots, HRV of various mental and physical work stresses were investigated. For the physical stress on the treadmill, S.D. of heart rate sequence showed a minimum value at medium stresses and remained there until the maximum stress.</excerpt>

affiliations: Branch Clin., MS, United States
title: Case report of an obsessive-compulsive personality: A precursor to accident proneness
doc: <title>Case report of an obsessive-compulsive personality: A precursor to accident proneness</title> <excerpt>The social/physiological/psychological review of an aircraft accident involving input of incorrect controls and low-altitude ejection of a student naval aviator enlightened the investigators as to maybe a not-so-uncommon problem, accident proneness resulting from an obsessive-compulsive nonpsychotic personality. Review of the pilot's history reflected a perfectionist attitude since childhood with continuous associated near-serious accidents. Flight training revealed occurrences of over-correction, channelized attention, and denial of errors.</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Comparison of the vigilance performance of men and women using a simulated radar task
doc: <title>Comparison of the vigilance performance of men and women using a simulated radar task</title> <excerpt>The present study examined the question of possible sex differences in the ability to sustain attention to a complex monitoring task requiring only a detection response to critical stimulus changes. The visual display was designed to approximate a futuristic, highly automated air traffic control radar display containing computer-generated alphanumeric symbols. There were 26 men and 26 women tested, each over a 2-h session.</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aviation Authority, London, Engl, United Kingdom
title: Workload and fatigue - in-flight EEG changes
doc: <title>Workload and fatigue - in-flight EEG changes</title> <excerpt>Continuous recordings were made of the EEG and ECG of one pilot during a series of instrument flights in a feeder-type transport aircraft. The flights were arranged to contain epochs of distinctly differing levels of workload. In addition, some flights were made after a night of sleep deprivation and others were made as the second and third flights of the day.</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Use of path models to study a precareer air traffic control training program
doc: <title>Use of path models to study a precareer air traffic control training program</title> <excerpt>Past studies have demonstrated that women and minorities are less likely to be selected as FAA air traffic controllers than are nonminority men and, when selected, are less likely to be successful. One major reason for this is that women and minorities have less aviation-related background experience. In response to this need the '150' Predevelopmental program was begun to give those selected for the program a 1-year orientation to aviation and air traffic control prior to FAA Academy training.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Aerospace Medical Research Laboratory, Pensacola, FL, United States
