doc: <title>Back to basics: suggested solutions to some flight instruction problems</title> <excerpt>Since 1976 a series of surveys of flight instructors and students in general and commercial aviation, and the Royal Australian Air Force, has indicated several common problems in flight instruction. These problems have provided a focus for instructor education programs described in this paper. Professional preparation of instructions in areas such as educational psychology (learning and memory, motivation, and skill acquisition) met with the approval of the participants, but no detectable change in instructional methods resulted.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Management Sciences, The University of Manchester, Manchester, Greater Manchester, United Kingdom
title: The stress of work: An overview
doc: <title>The stress of work: An overview</title> <excerpt>This paper looks at a number of potential occupational stressors found to predict job dissatisfaction and ill health (both mental and physical) in a variety of different occupational settings. Factors intrinsic to the nature of the job, role ambiguity and conflict, poor relationships at work, lack of career development, inadequate organisation structure/climate, and problems associated with the interface between work and homelife are the focal points of attention. Many of these sources of occupational stress are prevalent in the field of aviation, and may be exacerbated by the move toward deregulation and increasing commercial competition within the industry..</excerpt>

affiliations: San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
title: Off-vertical rotation produces conditioned taste aversion and suppressed drinking in mice
doc: <title>Off-vertical rotation produces conditioned taste aversion and suppressed drinking in mice</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Army Personnel Research Establishment, Farnborough, Engl, United Kingdom
title: The military performance of soldiers in sustained operations
doc: <title>The military performance of soldiers in sustained operations</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Mather Air Force Base, Mather, CA, United States
title: Motion sickness susceptibility in student navigators
doc: <title>Motion sickness susceptibility in student navigators</title> <excerpt>Identification of individuals highly susceptible to motion sickness could be of significant benefit in managing flying personnel in training. Several studies in the past four decades with this end have been primarily aimed at pilot trainees. The following study is a prospective evaluation of airsickness in Air Force navigation students.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Public Health and Preventive Medicine, Oregon Health & Science University, Portland, OR, United States
title: Ethical dilemmas and nursing
doc: <title>Ethical dilemmas and nursing</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aviation Authority, London, United Kingdom
title: Pointers to diagnosis of psychiatric illness in aircrew
doc: <title>Pointers to diagnosis of psychiatric illness in aircrew</title> <excerpt>Diagnosis of psychiatric illnesses in aircrew is made by assessing the symptoms complained of by the patient or observed by others. Symptoms should be matched against the textbook description of psychiatric disease: if the match is good, a diagnosis of psychiatric ill health is made. Subtle questioning of patients concerning psychiatric symptoms such as smoking and alcohol is required, and facial expression and demeanor comprise important diagnostic factors.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aviat. Psychol. Lab., Claremont McKenna College, Claremont, CA, United States
title: Locus of control, self-serving biases, and attitudes towards safety in general aviation pilots
doc: <title>Locus of control, self-serving biases, and attitudes towards safety in general aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>Of the three related survey studies that were conducted, two are summarized and one, which characterizes all three, is reported in detail. The studies attempted to determine how aviators compared with the general population on the personality dimension - locus of control (internal vs external) and how this was related to aviators' attenance at FAA Safety Clinics. In addition, aviators were surveyed regarding their attituds towards safety, their flying skill, and the likelihood that they would have an accident during the remainder of their careers.</excerpt>

title: The Wright brothers: a personality profile.
doc: <title>The Wright brothers: a personality profile.</title> <excerpt>Wilbur and Orville Wright were able, as a team, to develop the first heavier than air machine capable of sustained, controlled, powered flight while piloted by a man. This was due, very possibly, to the presence of a left hemispheric dominant personality in Wilbur Wright and a right hemispheric dominant personality in Orville Wright. They were thus able to complement each other's skills and creativity in such a way as to make this feat possible.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, Aurora, CO, United States
title: Neuropsychological functioning after prolonged high altitude exposure in mountaineering
doc: <title>Neuropsychological functioning after prolonged high altitude exposure in mountaineering</title> <excerpt>This prospective study examined the possibility of long lasting CNS sequelae of high altitude exposure in mountaineering. An extensive battery of neuropsychological and personality tests was given to 22 subjects before and after Himalayan climbs above 5334m (17,500 ft). All subjects were at altitude for long periods without supplemental oxygen, but did not suffer other physical insults such as serious injury or food or water deprivation.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of California, San Francisco, San Francisco, CA, United States
title: Reducing motion sickness: A comparison of autogenic-feedback training and an alternative cognitive task
doc: <title>Reducing motion sickness: A comparison of autogenic-feedback training and an alternative cognitive task</title> <excerpt>Eighteen men were randomly assigned to three groups matched for susceptibility to Coriolis motion sickness. All subjects were given six Coriolis Sickness Susceptibility Index (CSSI) tests separated by 5-d intervals. Treatment Group I subjects were taught to control their own autonomic responses before the third, fourth, and fifth CSSI tests (6 h total training).</excerpt>

affiliations: Aerospace Med. Res. Lab., Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Subjective response to negative air ion exposure
doc: <title>Subjective response to negative air ion exposure</title> <excerpt>This study investigated specific subjective or psychological effects of relatively long exposure to negative ions generated by a conventional air purification device. Subjects - 24 males matched for age, education, physical condition, and smoking habits - were divided into a control (N=12) and an ion exposure group (N=12). The groups were subjected to 6 h normal and negatively charged atmospheres, respectively.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Submarine Base New London, New London, CT, United States
title: Relationship of personality factors and some social habits to cardiovascular risk in submariners
doc: <title>Relationship of personality factors and some social habits to cardiovascular risk in submariners</title> <excerpt>Correlation and contingency analytical techniques were used to investigate the relationship between subtest scores on the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI) and coronary heart disease (CHD) risk factors in 1000 submariners. Groups of pesonality traits, both enhancing and protecting against risk of heart disease, were identified in these subjects. Personality trait patterns tending to be least associated with cardiovascular risk are tentatively identified by the three MMPI scales: psychasthenia, schizophrenia, and social introversion.</excerpt>

affiliations: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, NY, United States
title: Psychological testing at high altitudes
doc: <title>Psychological testing at high altitudes</title> <excerpt>Psychological testing was done on 20 subjects at various altitudes (sea level, 3,810 m, and 5,000 m) during a 35-d mountaineering expedition to Denali (Mt. McKinley). Intellectual functioning and personality changes were studied.</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Air Force School of Aerospace Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Values clarification and the post-myocardial infarction patient
doc: <title>Values clarification and the post-myocardial infarction patient</title> <excerpt>Marked changes in an individual's attitudes and actions are frequently due to severe or prolonged conditions of stress. A stress encountered by the myocardial infarction patient is the anxiety or depression induced by the forced reduction of activities. Values clarification may be utilized to assist the patient to sort out those activities that are truly important, thus decreasing tension and anxiety.</excerpt>

affiliations: Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel
title: Prediction of success in a stressful career by personality attributes
doc: <title>Prediction of success in a stressful career by personality attributes</title> <excerpt>Several personality attributes were hypothesized to account for a part of the performance variability in continuous repetitive and real-stress situations. A Personality Inventory For Divers (PIFD) was administered to 518 divers and non-divers. Cross sectional and longitudinal studies supported the validity of the PIFD (p<0.05).</excerpt>

affiliations: West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk, United Kingdom
title: The effect of propranolol on human psychomotor performance
doc: <title>The effect of propranolol on human psychomotor performance</title> <excerpt>Despite their widespread usage the effect of beta blockers on human performance has been only sparsely studied and results of investigations are discrepant. This study examines the effect of one of the most commonly prescribed beta adrenergic blocking drugs, propranolol, on psychomotor function. To demonstrate the sensitivity of the test method and to provide some basis for comparison, the effect of small doses of sodium amylobarbitone on psychomotor performance is also measured.</excerpt>

affiliations: VA Nebraska Western Iowa Health Care System Omaha Division, Omaha, NE, United States
title: Minimizing the psychological effects of a wartime disaster on an individual
doc: <title>Minimizing the psychological effects of a wartime disaster on an individual</title> <excerpt>In this paper, the psychological reactions of individuals and groups to a wartime disaster, such as nuclear explosion, are presented. The psychological literature on disasters is discussed. The presentation attempts to emphasize viewing the victims of a disaster as individuals responding in a normal way to an overwhelming experience, rather than labeling them as psychiatric patients.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
title: Comparison of two techniques for the development and maintenance of tracking behavior in monkeys
doc: <title>Comparison of two techniques for the development and maintenance of tracking behavior in monkeys</title> <excerpt>The present study compared two methods by which animal subjects can be taught to perform a pursuit tracking task. Rhesus monkeys were trained to track in order to avoid shock (Method #1) to obtain food (Method #2). One animal received training under both procedures.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute for Biomedical Problems, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
title: Psychological compatibility on Earth and in outer space
doc: <title>Psychological compatibility on Earth and in outer space</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, United States
title: Carbon monoxide and human time discrimination: Failure to replicate Beard-Wertheim experiments
doc: <title>Carbon monoxide and human time discrimination: Failure to replicate Beard-Wertheim experiments</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Norwegian Defence Research Establishment, Skedsmokorset, Akershus, Norway
title: Performance, mood, and clinical symptoms in men exposed to prolonged, severe physical work and sleep deprivation
doc: <title>Performance, mood, and clinical symptoms in men exposed to prolonged, severe physical work and sleep deprivation</title> <excerpt>There were 44 young men who participated in strenuous combat courses of 4 d (course I) or 5 d (course II), almost without sleep. They were tested and examined clinically each morning. Groups 1 and 2 had no organized sleep, whereas groups 3 and 4 got 3 and 6 h, respectively, in the middle of each course.</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aeromedical Institute, FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Effects of ground trainer use on the anxiety of students in private pilot training
doc: <title>Effects of ground trainer use on the anxiety of students in private pilot training</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Some psychological correlates of motion sickness susceptibility
doc: <title>Some psychological correlates of motion sickness susceptibility</title> <excerpt>Four groups of 37 subjects each (highly susceptible men, highly susceptible women, nonsusceptible men, and nonsusceptible women) were obtained from a population of 2,432 college students ranging in age from 18 to 39 years. Susceptibility to motion sickness was determined by scores on a motion sickness questionnaire (MSQ); only individuals with extreme scores were considered for inclusion in the experimental groups. The following tests were administered: Floor Ataxia Test Battery, State Trait Anxiety Inventory, Menstrual Distress Questionnaire, Cornell Medical Index, Cornell Word Form, Eysenck Personality Inventory, Rotter Internal External Locus of Control Scale, and the 16 Personality Factors test.</excerpt>

affiliations: United States Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine, Natick, MA, United States
title: Self rated moods of humans at 4300 m pretreated with placebo or acetazolamide plus staging
doc: <title>Self rated moods of humans at 4300 m pretreated with placebo or acetazolamide plus staging</title> <excerpt>Self-rated moods were determined twice daily with the Clyde Mood Scale on 35 human subjects at 200 m (baseline) during a study concerned with evaluating the efficacy of staging plus acetazolamide (treatment) for the prevention of acute mountain sickness (AMS). Mood states also were determined on all subjects at 4300 m (Pikes Peak, Co) and on 18 of these subjects at 1600 m (staging site). Mood state changes were not observed at 1600 m, but four of the six mood factors were sensitive to the 4300 m altitude.</excerpt>

title: Psychological considerations with patients on respirators
doc: <title>Psychological considerations with patients on respirators</title> <excerpt>Illness is a subjective experience for patients and, as such, responses to illness are as varied as the patients' personalities. Special psychological considerations are necessary when delivering care to patients on respirators since they, more than others, are dependent upon people and machines for each breath of life. Providing active psychological support systems requires an awareness of the Intensive Care Unit environment, patients responses to illness and the environment, and implementation of appropriate psychological intervention.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Higher Nervous Activity and Neurophysiology of RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation
title: Analysis of the human voice as a method of controlling emotional state: Achievements and goals
doc: <title>Analysis of the human voice as a method of controlling emotional state: Achievements and goals</title> <excerpt>Background factors and those of formant structure, spectral and spectro temporal characteristics of rapid and slow speech components, temporal peculiarities, and intensity of speech turned out to be informative indices of the human emotional state. Application of mathematical methods, in particular methods of recognition theory, to these factors helped to assess the degree and the psychological sign of emotion, to diagnose the status of attention and fatigue, and to differentiate emotional and physical stress. The paper outlines the results obtained in model experiments on cosmonaut A.</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Some behavioral effects of pesticides: the interaction of mevinphos and atropine in pigeons
doc: <title>Some behavioral effects of pesticides: the interaction of mevinphos and atropine in pigeons</title> <excerpt>The interaction of the organophosphate mevinphos and atropine was examined in two pigeons performing in a variable interval schedule of reinforcement. When administered separately, both atropine and mevinphos produced a dose related decrement in responding. The combined exposure to these drugs produced a performance decrement greater than that caused by exposure to each component drug alone.</excerpt>

affiliations: Łukasiewicz - Instytut Lotnictwa, Warsaw, MA, Poland
title: Alpha index and personality traits of pilots
doc: <title>Alpha index and personality traits of pilots</title> <excerpt>This investigation was instituted to provide information regarding the relationship between individuals with radically different alpha indices (low vs high) and personality traits of the subjects. EEG recordings were obtained and acceptable diagnostic personality testing techniques administered. The results indicate that the group with low alpha index revealed a significantly higher level of anxiety and neuroticism..</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Army Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Novosel, AL, United States
title: Cross validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents
doc: <title>Cross validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents</title> <excerpt>Pilot error accidents have dominated accident statistics consistently from the 1940s to the present. In an earlier study the authors found that three factors from Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF) exhibited significant differences (p<0.05) between pilot error accident groups; these were used to correctly classify 86% of the aviators tested as to their previous pilot error accident involvement. There were 66 aviators given the 16 PF in the present study in an attempt to cross validate the findings reported in the original study.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychiatry, UC Davis School of Medicine, Sacramento, CA, United States
title: Psychologic and psychophysiologic response to 105 days of social isolation
doc: <title>Psychologic and psychophysiologic response to 105 days of social isolation</title> <excerpt>The responses of nine subjects to 105 d of social isolation are reported. The study reveals that crew selection plus ongoing support by psychiatric staff permits continued function in an exotic milieu. Prediction of psychophysiologic symptoms was possible using paper and pencil tests.</excerpt>

affiliations: Federal Aviation Administration, Washington, D.C., United States
title: Federal Aviation Administration's behavioral research program for defense against hijackings
doc: <title>Federal Aviation Administration's behavioral research program for defense against hijackings</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, United States
title: Assessment of seasickness and its consequences by a method of peer evaluation
doc: <title>Assessment of seasickness and its consequences by a method of peer evaluation</title> <excerpt>A Seasickness Questionnaire, based on a peer rating technique, was administered to 172 Israeli Navy sailors. Use of interrater agreement as a reliability index and 2 cutoff points for the partition of the sample resulted in the elimination of about 1/3 of the initial sample and the formation of 2 subsamples: the 'sick' (N = 45) and 'not sick' (N = 73) sailors. By using differentially weighted scores for various intensities of seasickness, it was demonstrated that 2 normally confounded aspects of seasickness can be assessed independently: physical symptoms, which constitute the apparent severity of the sickness (A.S.S.), and level of actual performance (A.P.), which reflects the individual's attempts to cope with the sickness.</excerpt>

affiliations: Direct. Aerospace Safety, Norton AFB, San Bernardino, CA, United States
title: Human factors in Air Force aircraft accidents
doc: <title>Human factors in Air Force aircraft accidents</title> <excerpt>Advances have been made in the design and reliability of Air Force aircraft; however, there continues to be materiel failure accidents. The design of man has not changed, although training programs have been improved to reduce accidents caused by human error. This study was conducted to determine the human factors causation of aircraft accidents.</excerpt>

affiliations: Submar. Developm. Group One, San Diego, CA, United States
title: Psychological characteristics of deep submergence vehicle personnel
doc: <title>Psychological characteristics of deep submergence vehicle personnel</title> <excerpt>The personality and developmental characteristics of US Navy Deep Submergence Vehicle (DSV) personnel, including operators and crews, were documented and compared to the characteristics of US Navy divers. The results show that DSV operators (DSV Oprs) had a significantly less asocial developmental pattern than divers, while developmental experiences of DSV crews (DSV Crs) were similar to those of divers. Personality measures (EPPS) indicate that both DSV Oprs and DSV Crs are presently more sociable as adults than divers and would probably be more effective in situations involving small group interaction.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Portland State University, Portland, OR, United States
title: Rat operant responding: an indicator of nitrogen narcosis?
doc: <title>Rat operant responding: an indicator of nitrogen narcosis?</title> <excerpt>One group of rats was stabilized on a variable ratio (VR) 50 schedule and another on a differential reinforcement of low rate (DRL) 20 s schedule. Four subgroups in each were exposed to 1, 7.1, 10.2, or 13.3 ATA for 30 min once a week for 6 weeks with a seventh exposure after a 4 week hiatus. At 10.2 and 13.3 ATA, DRL 20 s response rate increased and VR 50 decreased.</excerpt>

affiliations: U.S. Army Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Novosel, AL, United States
title: Personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents
doc: <title>Personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents</title> <excerpt>The consistently high frequency of pilot error accidents in both military and civilian aviation programs does much to support exploratory research which might help alleviate the problem. Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF), Mehrabian Achievement Scale, and a dynamic decision making task (under risk) were given to 51 Army aviators. Accident files were then examined in order to classify the aviators as to their prior pilot error accident involvement.</excerpt>

affiliations: Eastern Michigan University, Ypsilanti, MI, United States
title: Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller
doc: <title>Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller</title> <excerpt>Based on scores from the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire, the personality structure of 11,047 persons working as air traffic controllers, and 9886 persons applying for that job, was examined through factor analytic and analysis of variance techniques. It was concluded that air traffic controllers are superior to the general population in all characteristics of personality essential to performance of their work and, further, that applicants for these positions are even better qualified in certain respects..</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States
title: Regularity in the control of the free running sleep wakefulness rhythm
doc: <title>Regularity in the control of the free running sleep wakefulness rhythm</title> <excerpt>The natural tendency of humans to lengthen their sleep wakefulness cycle in environments which minimize natural cues to time of day poses problems for designing efficient work schedules. In the present experiment, rigid control over the sleep and wake up times was employed in an attempt to contain the natural rhythm to a 24 h cycle. Eight subjects were isolated from all time and social cues for 10 d.</excerpt>

affiliations: Eastern Michigan University, Ypsilanti, MI, United States
title: Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants
doc: <title>Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants</title> <excerpt>Differences in personality structure between 9,886 male and 217 female applicants for air traffic control positions were examined, using the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire. Data were analyzed through the analysis of variance, and factor analytic techniques. It was shown through both methods that the personality structure of male and female applicants for these positions is much more similar than dissimilar..</excerpt>

affiliations: Off. Aviat. Med., Federal Aviation Administration, Washington, D.C., United States
title: Aircraft as an instrument of self destruction
doc: <title>Aircraft as an instrument of self destruction</title> <excerpt>Often the relationship between the pilot and his aircraft is such that the aircraft may be thought of as an extension of the pilot himself during the act of flight. If this pilot accumulates stress in his life with which he can no longer adequately cope, he may engage in self destructive acts, some of these within the context of his flying activities. The competent pilot practices and acquires skills which help him deal with the stress of demanding flight situations.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Medical Center San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States
title: Social development of navy divers
doc: <title>Social development of navy divers</title> <excerpt>Ninety five U.S. Navy divers and 93 fleet controls, matched for age, rate, pay grade, and the age at which they joined the Navy, were compared for several important biographical characteristics. The divers were found to be similar to controls in education, present marital status, educational level of parents, marital status of parents, number of brothers and sisters, number of moves made before joining the Navy, and size of hometown.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aerospace Med. Div., Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Human performance at elevated environmental temperatures
doc: <title>Human performance at elevated environmental temperatures</title> <excerpt>A review of research on human performance at elevated temperatures is presented. The findings are analyzed in terms of 5 categories of performance measurements: time estimation; reaction time; vigilance and monitoring; tracking; and cognitive and other skilled tasks. Time estimation studies, requiring subjects to count or tap at specified rates, generally show increased speed of response with elevation of internal body temperature.</excerpt>

affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Washington, D.C., DC, United States
title: View of human problems to be addressed for long duration space flights
doc: <title>View of human problems to be addressed for long duration space flights</title> <excerpt>After 9,501 man hours in space, no physiological problems serious enough to cause lasting medical concern have been seen among U.S. astronauts. Heart rates tend to stabilize at lower levels in zero gravity and electrical activity, except for occasional bigeminis and premature auricular and ventricular contractions (Apollo 15), is normal.</excerpt>

title: Some aversive characteristics of centrifugally generated gravity.
doc: <title>Some aversive characteristics of centrifugally generated gravity.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

title: Physiological effects of backscatter of high intensity light pulses on the human pilot.
doc: <title>Physiological effects of backscatter of high intensity light pulses on the human pilot.</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aviation and Space Psychology, Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (DLR), Koln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; Personnel Department, Police Academy Hamburg, Hamburg, Germany; Maritime Medical Service, BG Verkehr, Hamburg, Germany; DFS Deutsche Flugsicherung GmbH, Langen, Germany
title: Predictive Validity of Selection and Training for Ab Initio Air Traffic Controllers
doc: <title>Predictive Validity of Selection and Training for Ab Initio Air Traffic Controllers</title> <excerpt>The German Aerospace Center (DLR) provides a selection procedure to identify suitable applicants for ab initio air traffic controller (ATCO) training at DFS Deutsche Flugsicherung GmbH. The selection phases comprise cognitive and work sample tests, team exercises, and an interview with a final assessment by a selection board. DFS ATCO training consists of initial training (IT) and unit training (UT).</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, University of the Bundeswehr Munich, Neubiberg, Bayern, Germany; Department of Psychology, Universität Zürich, Zurich, ZH, Switzerland
title: The Invisible Copilot?: Assessing Task Engagement and Team Dynamics in a Virtual Flight Environment Using Eye-Tracking Metrics
doc: <title>The Invisible Copilot?: Assessing Task Engagement and Team Dynamics in a Virtual Flight Environment Using Eye-Tracking Metrics</title> <excerpt>Gaze behavior represents a vital predictor of flight performance in pilots operating an aircraft. However, its role in collaborative settings with a copilot has been largely disregarded. Our study addressed this gap by simulating a flight environment with role division into a pilot flying (PF) and pilot monitoring (PM).</excerpt>

affiliations: École de l’Air et de l'Espace, Salon-de-Provence, Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur, France; Communauté d'universités et établissements de Toulouse, Toulouse, Occitanie, France; Airbus Protect, Vitrolles, France
title: Effect of Pilot Expertise on Visual Scanning and Precision of Flight Maneuvers in Military Aviation
doc: <title>Effect of Pilot Expertise on Visual Scanning and Precision of Flight Maneuvers in Military Aviation</title> <excerpt>This study explored how expertise affects visual scanning strategies and the precision of flight maneuvers in military aviation. A total of 38 French Air Force pilots of three different expertise levels performed horizontal and vertical maneuvers in a flight simulator. Flight performance analysis showed that novices had larger deviations in roll, heading, and speed compared to cadets and experts, underlining the role of expertise on the precision of flight maneuvers.</excerpt>

affiliations: École de l’Air et de l'Espace, Salon-de-Provence, Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur, France; ONERA Office National d'Etudes et Recherches Aerospatiales, Palaiseau, Ile-de-France, France
title: Could Pilots and Controllers Learn to Adequately Trust Their Partners?: A First Experimental Response
doc: <title>Could Pilots and Controllers Learn to Adequately Trust Their Partners?: A First Experimental Response</title> <excerpt>To find out whether it is possible to train pilots and controllers to adequately trust their partners, and thus modify their behavior and increase their performance, this study experimentally tested whether individuals disposition to trust is influenced by their social learning. Objective measurements related to the task to perform, collected over two successive phases, were used for two different groups of aviation staff. The results highlight a link between swift trust, supervision strategies, and time management and point to the social nature of the disposition to trust.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Transportation and Communication Management Science, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan
title: Modelling Pilot Decisions During One Engine Inoperative in Maritime SAR Helicopter Hoist Task: RPDM and PCM
doc: <title>Modelling Pilot Decisions During One Engine Inoperative in Maritime SAR Helicopter Hoist Task: RPDM and PCM</title> <excerpt>This paper undertakes a comprehensive examination of pilot decision-making in response to a single-engine failure during maritime search and rescue (SAR) helicopter hoist tasks, employing two distinct decision models–namely, RPDM and PCM. The primary goal of this research is to assess the strengths and weaknesses of each model in accounting for the decision-making processes involved in this critical scenario. Through a comparative analysis, the findings indicate that the PCM encompasses a more extensive array of steps related to emergency evacuation procedures and emphasizes the importance of awaiting the search and rescue (SAR) team to maximize survivability.</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Aviation, UNSW Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia
title: Pilot-Related Factors Involved in Runway Incursions: An Epidemiological Approach
doc: <title>Pilot-Related Factors Involved in Runway Incursions: An Epidemiological Approach</title> <excerpt>Objective: This research investigates the role of pilot deviation in runway incursions, a persistent safety risk for aviation safety. Background: Despite many research efforts focusing primarily on the evaluation of advanced technical systems as mitigation solutions, there remains a significant lack of studies investigating the central figure in this issue: the pilot, as well as the underlying human factors and mitigating circumstances that contribute to runway incursions. Method: An in-depth analysis of incident and accident reports from 1993 to 2021, sourced from both Australia and the United States was employed.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aviation Management, R.O.C. Air Force Academy, Gangshan, Taiwan; Department of Applied Foreign Languages, R.O.C. Air Force Academy, Gangshan, Taiwan
title: Gamification of Learning Aviation Knowledge for Improving the Efficiency of Flight Training
doc: <title>Gamification of Learning Aviation Knowledge for Improving the Efficiency of Flight Training</title> <excerpt>Objective: The goal of the present study was to determine whether using gamification with the flexibility of board game design to prepare aviation cadets for future flight training could reduce their fatigue and stress from work overload and thereby decrease risk of human error leading to accidents. Background: Cadets need to have fully acquired aviation knowledge so as be able to access it spontaneously in decision-making when operating an aircraft and performing multi-tasks. The current tight training schedule and the need to immediately apply newly learned knowledge add considerable stress to the fatigue resulting from highly demanding physical training.</excerpt>

affiliations: Administration Department, Indiana Aerospace University, Lapu-Lapu City, Philippines; Avionics Department, Indiana Aerospace University, Lapu-Lapu City, Philippines; Teacher Education Department, Indiana Aerospace University, Lapu-Lapu City, Philippines; On-the-Job Training Office, Indiana Aerospace University, Lapu-Lapu City, Philippines; Department of Pure Sciences, Cebu Technological University, Cebu, Cebu, Philippines; Department of English Language and Literary Studies, Cebu Technological University, Cebu, Cebu, Philippines
title: The Use of Hedonic-Motivation System Adoption Model in Evaluating Aviation Technology students’ Behavioral Intention and Immersion Toward Using Flight Simulator
doc: <title>The Use of Hedonic-Motivation System Adoption Model in Evaluating Aviation Technology students’ Behavioral Intention and Immersion Toward Using Flight Simulator</title> <excerpt>Background: In aviation education, flight simulators are required instructional infrastructures, but there is a scarcity of studies exploring students’ behavioral intention and immersion to use these technologies within the lens of Hedonic–Motivation System Adoption Model. Methods: Using quantitative cross-sectional survey design, 241 aviation technology students participated in an online survey. Results: The structural equation modeling reveals that most of the hypothesized paths are supported except the influence of joy to immersion.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aviation Technologies, Vilniaus Gedimino Technikos Universitetas, Vilnius, Lithuania; Institute of Psychology, Vilniaus Universitetas, Vilnius, Vilnius, Lithuania; Department of Aerospace Engineering, Vilniaus Gedimino Technikos Universitetas, Vilnius, Lithuania
title: A Comparative Study of Cognitive Abilities of Generation Y and Generation Z Pilot Candidates
doc: <title>A Comparative Study of Cognitive Abilities of Generation Y and Generation Z Pilot Candidates</title> <excerpt>Objective: Training aviation specialists is a complex and rigorous process. According to statistics, 75% of incidents negatively impacting flight safety have been caused by human error. This article analyzes the admission process to aircraft piloting studies, which has remained unchanged over the last decade.</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Psychology and Wellbeing, University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, QLD, Australia
title: Why Pilots Push On: Motivational Influences on Weather-Related Risk Appraisal in Small Airplane and Helicopter Operations
doc: <title>Why Pilots Push On: Motivational Influences on Weather-Related Risk Appraisal in Small Airplane and Helicopter Operations</title> <excerpt>This study explores the multilevel influences associated with commercial pilots’ risk appraisal when deciding whether to continue a flight into deteriorating conditions, focusing on small airplane and helicopter commercial operations in Australia and New Zealand. Deductive content analysis of online survey responses identified congruences with the extant literature. Commercial/financial and customer pressures were discovered as major external influences.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Reykjavík University, Reykjavik, Iceland
title: Meta-Analysis of Age and Student Air Traffic Controller (ATCO) Training Outcomes
doc: <title>Meta-Analysis of Age and Student Air Traffic Controller (ATCO) Training Outcomes</title> <excerpt>Some air navigation service providers (ANSPs) set a maximum age for entry into the air traffic controller (ATCO) occupation. Are such rules justified by empirical evidence? A recent meta-analysis of four studies reported no relationship between age at entry and training outcomes. Drawing on a larger number of studies (k = 8, N = 34,389) spanning 60 years, the age-training outcome relationship was investigated in a "bare bones"random-effect meta-analysis (without correction for artifacts or moderator analyses).</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Organization, Open Universiteit, Heerlen, Limburg, Netherlands; Department of Psychology, Universitatea Babeș-Bolyai, Cluj Napoca, Cluj, Romania
title: Anthropomorphic AI: Sociopathic AI Features as Predictors of Career Opportunities and Threats Perceived by Pilots in Commercial Aviation
doc: <title>Anthropomorphic AI: Sociopathic AI Features as Predictors of Career Opportunities and Threats Perceived by Pilots in Commercial Aviation</title> <excerpt>Objective: The study aims to investigate how anthropomorphic, particularly sociopathic, features ascribed to AI affect commercial pilots’ perceptions of career threats, opportunities, and performance benefits of AI integration in the cockpit. Background: Although technology has long been an irreplaceable, valuable ally for airline pilots, artificial intelligence (AI) differs significantly from previously used technologies and pilots perceive AI not only as a tool but as an agent with human-like attributes. These anthropomorphic perceptions shape their career-related attitudes, especially as AI’s cognitive capabilities and ethical limitations challenge pilot identity.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Tehran, Iran
title: Relationships Between Pilot Gaze Patterns and Control Lapses in Challenging Instrument Approach Flight
doc: <title>Relationships Between Pilot Gaze Patterns and Control Lapses in Challenging Instrument Approach Flight</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study investigates the link between pilot gaze patterns and control deviations during simulated instrument flight approaches, aiming to understand how attentional focus impacts flight safety. Background: Building on previous research that underscores the importance of situational awareness in aviation, this work delves into the specific aspects of gaze behavior as indicators of cognitive workload and attentional distribution. Unlike prior studies that broadly assessed attentional markers, this research utilizes advanced iris tracking technology to pinpoint how gaze metrics correlate with flight performance.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States; Department of Aviation, University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, ND, United States
title: Total and Recent Flight Experience as Predictors of Pilot Instrument Performance
doc: <title>Total and Recent Flight Experience as Predictors of Pilot Instrument Performance</title> <excerpt>Objective: The present research sought to investigate the impact of total flight time and recent flight time on instrument flight performance. Background: Studies that examined the impact of total flight time and recent flight time on pilot proficiency and have reported mixed results for both total time and recent flight time. The present study examined the impact of total and recent flight time along with vocabulary and mental rotation on instrument flight performance.</excerpt>

affiliations: Environment and Computing, Coventry University, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom
title: Single Pilot Concept of Operations: Hazard Identification and Mitigation Measures
doc: <title>Single Pilot Concept of Operations: Hazard Identification and Mitigation Measures</title> <excerpt>Objective: This work identifies the human factors hazards associated with Single Pilot Operations (SiPO) in small jets currently certified for single-pilot operations and assesses their transferability to future airliner single-pilot concept. Background: SiPO of commercial airliners is imminent. Hazard identification of SiPO based upon an extant similar system could contribute to proving SiPO equally safe to multicrew operations (MCO).</excerpt>

country: Croatia - Hong Kong - Korea, Republic of - Macao - Malaysia - Spain - United States
affiliations: Faculty of Hospitality and Tourism Management, Macau University of Science and Technology, Taipa, Macao; Independent Researcher, Dubrovnik, Croatia; Social Matters Research Group, Universidad Loyola Andalucia, Cordoba, Cordoba, Spain; Department of Food Service and Management, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia; College of Human Sciences, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, United States; School of Hotel and Tourism Management, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; College of Hospitality and Tourism Management, Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea
title: Cars are Ready to Fly: Urban Air Mobility and Psychological Process of Sustainable Travel Mode Choices
doc: <title>Cars are Ready to Fly: Urban Air Mobility and Psychological Process of Sustainable Travel Mode Choices</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study is designed to predict individuals’ pro-social behavior in their choice of travel modes. Specifically, the consumer adoption process and the norm activation model are incorporated as the overarching theoretical model in consideration of the relative advantages of urban air mobility. Background: Urban air mobility, the next generation urban transport system, is all set to fly.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Leadership Studies, Our Lady of the Lake University, San Antonio, TX, United States; Air and Space Biosciences Division, Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; H-E-B School of Business and Administration, University of the Incarnate Word, San Antonio, TX, United States
title: Two Theories, Two Tests, One Outcome: Indifference of the Indicator
doc: <title>Two Theories, Two Tests, One Outcome: Indifference of the Indicator</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study sought to investigate if the constructs measured by the MAB II and the MicroCog are related. The similarity of two tests designed using two theories was examined. Background: Distinctions between tests of general cognitive ability (g) versus specific abilities (s) have been investigated for over a century.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Flight Systems and Automatic Control, Technische Universität Darmstadt, Darmstadt, Hessen, Germany
title: Comparing UAV Pilots' Traffic Awareness: Proposed Traffic Display Design Versus an Airspace Observer
doc: <title>Comparing UAV Pilots' Traffic Awareness: Proposed Traffic Display Design Versus an Airspace Observer</title> <excerpt>The growing popularity of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has led to increased conflict and collision potential between manned and unmanned aircraft. Beyond the visual line of sight, UAV missions require an airspace observer, who may fail to provide accurate traffic information. This work proposes a novel traffic display design that provides conflict and avoidance maneuver guidance in addition to information on surrounding traffic.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aeronautical Accidents Investigation and Prevention Center (CENIPA), Brasília, Brazil; Postgraduate Program in Meteorology at the Institute of Geosciences, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil
title: Stress, Resilience, and Organizational Climate: A Study with Pilots of the Brazilian Air Force
doc: <title>Stress, Resilience, and Organizational Climate: A Study with Pilots of the Brazilian Air Force</title> <excerpt>Organizational climate, stress, resilience, and cortisol measures were investigated in pilots of the Brazilian Air Force (FAB). Studies indicate that these variables may be related to the physical and mental health, quality of life, and work of these professionals. A total of 112 FAB pilots participated in this study.</excerpt>

affiliations: Centre for Aviation Psychology, London, United Kingdom
title: Competency-Based Peer Support in Aviation: A Framework for Training Peers Within Peer Support Programs
doc: <title>Competency-Based Peer Support in Aviation: A Framework for Training Peers Within Peer Support Programs</title> <excerpt>In July 2018, the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (2018) issued Regulation (EU) 2018/1042, now (EU) 2020/745, which required all commercial air transport operators to implement a support program by February 14, 2021. This was initially aimed at pilots and formed part of the recommendations made after the pilot murder-suicide crash of Germanwings flight 9525 in March 2015. Pilot peer support is now considered vital in supporting crew well-being and in promoting aviation safety, alongside other initiatives (Federal Aviation Administration, 2024).</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Leinster, Ireland
title: How Pilot Fatigue Affects Operational Flight Risk in Scheduled Commercial Aviation
doc: <title>How Pilot Fatigue Affects Operational Flight Risk in Scheduled Commercial Aviation</title> <excerpt>Pilot fatigue remains a hazard in scheduled commercial aviation, contributing to 31 aircraft accidents between 2005 and 2022, according to International Air Transport Association statistics (2023). Therefore, this study further investigated fatigue and its impact on operational flight risk in commercial aviation. More than 16,000 safety reports were analyzed using mixed methods.</excerpt>

affiliations: Systems Analysis Laboratory, Aalto University, Espoo, Uusimaa, Finland; Department of Military Technology, Maanpuolustuskorkeakoulu, Finland, Helsinki, Finland; Environment and Computing, Coventry University, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom
title: Comparison of In-Flight and Post-Flight Use of NASA-TLX
doc: <title>Comparison of In-Flight and Post-Flight Use of NASA-TLX</title> <excerpt>The objective of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of airborne assignment of NASA-TLX scores. A total of 21 participants flew two simulated flying missions. In both missions, the participants' task was to fly an instrument landing system (ILS) approach, followed by a stabilized climbing turn maneuver.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Human Factors and Behavioral Neurobiology, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States; College of Aviation, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States
title: Development and Validation of a General Aviation Risk Perception Scale
doc: <title>Development and Validation of a General Aviation Risk Perception Scale</title> <excerpt>The aim of this study was to develop a psychometric tool for measuring pilot perceptions of risk, with a focus on risk in general aviation (GA) flying. Unlike other objective protocols that pilots adhere to (eg, checklists), assessing and responding to risk is a subjective task, making it challenging to evaluate. Previous research has developed scales that are either too generalized or have poor psychometric properties (ie, reliability and validity).</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Flight Systems, University of the Bundeswehr Munich, Neubiberg, Bayern, Germany
title: Triggering Cockpit Alerts Using an Eye-Tracking-Based Measure of Monitoring Performance
doc: <title>Triggering Cockpit Alerts Using an Eye-Tracking-Based Measure of Monitoring Performance</title> <excerpt>This study explored the potential for enhancing pilot performance via an alerting system that adapts according to an eye-trackingbased measure of monitoring. The novel measure combines gaze analysis with system state assessment to estimate the pilot's understanding of the current system state. On this basis, an alerting system was developed to direct pilot attention to unnoticed system state changes, thereby improving system state monitoring.</excerpt>

affiliations: Environment and Computing, Coventry University, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom
title: Development and Proof of Concept of a Predictive Model of Flight Deck Cognitive Workload
doc: <title>Development and Proof of Concept of a Predictive Model of Flight Deck Cognitive Workload</title> <excerpt>Workload can be regarded as the 'cost' (in information processing terms) of performing a given flight task. Predictive models of workload are valuable at the early stages of system design to identify potentially excessive demands on the human operator before major system development commences. This paper describes the early development of a task-based predictive workload method.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Navigation Services of Sweden (LFV), Malmo, Sweden; Engineering Psychology and Applied Cognitive Research, Technische Universität Dresden, Dresden, Sachsen, Germany
title: Investigating Fatigue in Operational Nightshifts A Study of Work-Sleep Organization in Air Traffic Control
doc: <title>Investigating Fatigue in Operational Nightshifts A Study of Work-Sleep Organization in Air Traffic Control</title> <excerpt>The study investigated sleepiness and fatigue in a single split nightshift arrangement in air traffic control. The arrangement included two mirrored nightshift types, with sleep and operational phases alternating once mid-shift. Sleep duration, subjective sleepiness, and fatigue as well as sustained attention, which have not been thoroughly studied to date, were examined.</excerpt>

affiliations: Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA, United States
title: Number of Interrupting Events Influences Response Time in Multitasking, but not Trust in Automation
doc: <title>Number of Interrupting Events Influences Response Time in Multitasking, but not Trust in Automation</title> <excerpt>Objective: The present study examined how the number of interrupting events (interruption load) influences the effect of task load on human-automation trust and resource allocation in a low-fidelity flight simulation environment. Background: Trust is one critical factor that influences successful human-automation interaction. In the previous research, operators reported lower trust scores and made fewer fixation toward an automated system, which assisted a task, when competing task in the same workspace demanded more attention from the operator.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders, Rocky Mountain University of Health Professions, Provo, UT, United States
title: Vowel Centered Accent Modification in Mandarin Chinese Speaking Pilot Candidates
doc: <title>Vowel Centered Accent Modification in Mandarin Chinese Speaking Pilot Candidates</title> <excerpt>Objective: To determine the effectiveness of vowel centered accent modification (VCAM) on percent vowels correct (PVC) in Mandarin-speaking Chinese pilot candidates at the word, phrase, and semi-structured speech levels to increase the likelihood of pilot candidates passing the International Civil Aviation Organization’s (ICAO) Level 4 English Proficiency Requirement. Method: This was a single-subject changing criterion design with six participants. Three target vowels and one control vowel were selected for each participant.</excerpt>

affiliations: Clinic of Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy, Yunus Emre State Hospital, Eskisehir, Eskisehir, Turkey
title: Effects of Aerobic Capacity on Cognitive Functions During Hypoxia
doc: <title>Effects of Aerobic Capacity on Cognitive Functions During Hypoxia</title> <excerpt>Objective: We aimed to investigate the role of aerobic capacity on cognitive functions during hypoxic conditions. Background: Possessing a mishap risk in aviation, acute hypobaric hypoxia has some negative effects on cognitive functions. Therefore, it is important to develop hypoxia tolerance to preserve the mental functions of pilots against possible hypoxic conditions during flight.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Istanbul Üniversitesi, Istanbul, Turkey; Department of Organizational Behavior, Istanbul Üniversitesi, Istanbul, Turkey
title: The Relationship Between Pilot Candidates’ Self-Control, Self-Efficacy and Training Performance in Terms of Safety Climate
doc: <title>The Relationship Between Pilot Candidates’ Self-Control, Self-Efficacy and Training Performance in Terms of Safety Climate</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study investigates the relationship between pilot candidates’ self-control, self-efficacy, and training performance in terms of safety climate. Background: Self-efficacy and safety climate are essential for the flight performance of pilots. However, the effect of self-control on flight performance has yet to be studied.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Shipping and Transportation Management, National Taiwan Ocean University, Keelung, Taiwan; APG Maintenance Section, Base Maintenance Department, Taoyuan, Taiwan
title: Cognition and Habit Alterations of Maintenance Crew in A-Checks for New-Generation Aircraft: The A350XWB
doc: <title>Cognition and Habit Alterations of Maintenance Crew in A-Checks for New-Generation Aircraft: The A350XWB</title> <excerpt>Background: Airlines should ensure reliable maintenance support for aircraft operations, especially when introducing new aircraft types. To realize alternations in technicians’ cognition and habit in executing routine checks is vital to identify and set training principles during starting stages of type changes. Method: This study compiled possible alterations for A350XWB maintenance from senior practitioners and then conducted a comprehensive survey of China Airlines A-check crew members.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute for Aviation Psychology Research, Istanbul Üniversitesi, Istanbul, Turkey; Department of Psychology, Istanbul Üniversitesi, Istanbul, Turkey
title: Psychometric Properties of the FAS and the FAM Questionnaires Assessing Flight Anxiety: A Turkish Community-Based Study
doc: <title>Psychometric Properties of the FAS and the FAM Questionnaires Assessing Flight Anxiety: A Turkish Community-Based Study</title> <excerpt>Objective: To conduct the Turkish adaptation of the Flight Anxiety Situations Questionnaire (FAS) and the Flight Anxiety Modality Questionnaire (FAM). Background: The FAS measures the anxiety levels in different flight situations, while FAM assesses the somatic and cognitive symptoms of anxiety or anticipatory anxiety in different flight situations. The FAS and the FAM have been adapted to different cultures and used in different studies.</excerpt>

affiliations: Totalforsvarets forskningsinstitut, Kista, Stockholm, Sweden; Department of Computer Science and Information Systems, Stockholms universitet, Stockholm, Stockholm, Sweden; Media Technology and Interaction Design, The Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm, Stockholms, Sweden; Swedish Armed Forces, Lulea, Sweden; Department of Man-Technology-Organisation, Totalforsvarets forskningsinstitut, Kista, Stockholm, Sweden
title: The Future of Fighter Pilot Training? Live Virtual Constructive in Large Force Exercises: Perceived and Expected Training Value
doc: <title>The Future of Fighter Pilot Training? Live Virtual Constructive in Large Force Exercises: Perceived and Expected Training Value</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study investigates whether and how perceived training value varies among fighter pilots participating in a large force exercise (LFE), and whether they expect Live Virtual Constructive (LVC) training to enhance training value of future LFEs. Background: LVC technology is maturing but its expected training value is under-investigated, especially regarding future LVC in LFEs. Method: Fighter pilots at a Live-flying LFE answered questionnaires, 120 responses were analyzed statistically.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Tourism and Recreation Management, Overseas Chinese University, Taichung, Taiwan; Department of Food and Beverage Management, Overseas Chinese University, Taichung, Taiwan
title: The Effect of Role Stress and Emotional Exhaustion on Well-being Among Pilots: The Moderating Effect of Leisure Participation
doc: <title>The Effect of Role Stress and Emotional Exhaustion on Well-being Among Pilots: The Moderating Effect of Leisure Participation</title> <excerpt>Background: Since the flight safety accident of Germanwings Airlines and the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic have happened in recent years, the mental state of civil aviation pilots has paid much attention. The work of civil aviation pilots has to face pressure from families, individuals, companies and other multi-faceted sources. Therefore, it may lead to negative work behaviors and performance, and even further affect flight safety.</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD, Australia; Faculty Business Partner, Charles Sturt University, Bathurst, NSW, Australia; Griffith Business School, Brisbane, QLD, Australia; Universidade de São Paulo, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
title: Observational Learning in Ab Initio Pilot Training The Challenges and Opportunities of Backseating Flight Observations
doc: <title>Observational Learning in Ab Initio Pilot Training The Challenges and Opportunities of Backseating Flight Observations</title> <excerpt>New learning and teaching techniques are required to reduce the length and costs of flight training while increasing its quality, such as observational learning, also known as backseating in aviation training. This study investigates the opportunities and challenges associated with backseating in an aircraft when another student is learning to fly. An ethnographic study of a flight school in Australia was conducted via observation and in-depth interviews.</excerpt>

affiliations: Waikato Institute of Technology, Hamilton, New Zealand; School of Aviation, Massey University, Palmerston North, MWT, New Zealand
title: Interactions With Technology in the Cockpit The Influence of the Affect Heuristic on Perceived Benefits and Risks of General Aviation Cockpit Technologies
doc: <title>Interactions With Technology in the Cockpit The Influence of the Affect Heuristic on Perceived Benefits and Risks of General Aviation Cockpit Technologies</title> <excerpt>Technological advancements have resulted in significant safety benefits in commercial aviation; however, in general aviation their adoption has been somewhat slow. It is therefore important to understand how pilots interact with technology, particularly in general aviation. This study explored whether the affect heuristic influenced pilots' perceptions of the benefits and risks of five cockpit technologies available in general aviation, with a particular focus on technologies that may assist weather-related decision-making.</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD, Australia; School of Education and Professional Studies, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
title: Measuring Presence and Situational Awareness in a Virtual Reality Flight Simulator
doc: <title>Measuring Presence and Situational Awareness in a Virtual Reality Flight Simulator</title> <excerpt>A sense of presence plays a significant role in virtual reality (VR) usability, yet there is limited research of its existence in a virtual reality flight simulator (VRFS). Similarly, there is scarce investigation of situational awareness (SA) in a VRFS. Consequently, this paper discusses an experiment that explored presence and SA in a VRFS.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; TiER1 Performance Solutions, Covington, KY, United States; CAE USA, Dayton, OH, United States; United States Air Force Academy, Colorado Springs, CO, United States
title: Mobility Aircrew Fatigue Perceptions and Mitigation Strategies
doc: <title>Mobility Aircrew Fatigue Perceptions and Mitigation Strategies</title> <excerpt>Mobility aircrew operate in unique, high-tempo environments resulting in susceptibility to fatigue. In the current study we examined fatigue perceptions and mitigation strategies before and during mission execution with questionnaires from 44 volunteers from a US Air Force air mobility squadron. Results suggest that fatigue is a serious safety-of-flight concern for the community; however, crews generally did not reference the available fatigue risk management (FRM) tool for missions.</excerpt>

affiliations: Nederlandse Organisatie voor toegepast natuurwetenschappelijk onderzoek- TNO, The Hague, Zuid-Holland, Netherlands; Department of Control and Operations, TU Delft, Delft, Zuid-Holland, Netherlands; Safety and Accident Investigation Centre, Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
title: Does Deliberately Going Beyond Alarms in Stall Recovery Exercises Lead to Negative Training?
doc: <title>Does Deliberately Going Beyond Alarms in Stall Recovery Exercises Lead to Negative Training?</title> <excerpt>We investigated whether deliberately going beyond alarms during aerodynamic stall recovery exercises may result in negative training. Two groups of 20 airline pilots received stall recovery training in a moving-base simulator. The “delayed-response” group induced the stall themselves.</excerpt>

affiliations: Garrecht Avionik GmbH, Walldorf, Germany
title: Confronting Aerotowing Experts with a New Phase-of-Flight Taxonomy for Towplanes
doc: <title>Confronting Aerotowing Experts with a New Phase-of-Flight Taxonomy for Towplanes</title> <excerpt>While designing an automated flight control system for aerotowing gliders, engineers realized that no suitable phase-of-flight taxonomy was available for performing a functional hazard assessment. As first experiences with a custom taxonomy were gathered, questions arose on how reproducible these results were and whether they could be applied to aerotow-related tasks outside the systems engineering domain. Inter-rater agreement, as one key metric of the taxonomy, was investigated by having 13 experts on aerotowing rate a total of 30 scenarios that are presented as photographs, video sequences, and textual narratives.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aeronautics, Florida Institute of Technology, Melbourne, FL, United States
title: The Effectiveness of Improving Flight Passengers' Safety Behaviors by Modifying Auditory Cues
doc: <title>The Effectiveness of Improving Flight Passengers' Safety Behaviors by Modifying Auditory Cues</title> <excerpt>The purpose of the study was to examine the effect of the intensive auditory cues on passengers performance and annoyance. It is critical to draw flight passengers attention and help them be aware of the importance of safety instructions. A total of 46 simulations were conducted to collect participants performance and annoyance when hearing auditory cues.</excerpt>

affiliations: UMR, Centre de Recherches sur la Cognition et l’Apprentissage, Poitiers, Nouvelle-Aquitaine, France; Centre d’études et de recherches psychologiques Air, Tours, France; Qualité de Vie et Santé Psychologique (Qualipsy) – EE 1901, Tours, Centre-Val de Loire, France
title: Crucial Abilities of Pilots and Weapon Systems Officers: An Ability-Based Approach
doc: <title>Crucial Abilities of Pilots and Weapon Systems Officers: An Ability-Based Approach</title> <excerpt>The first objective of our study was to identify the common and specific crucial abilities for fighter pilots, transport pilots, fighter weapon systems officers (WSOs), and transport WSOs. The second aim was to prioritize clusters of abilities. We used an online questionnaire to survey 479 expert pilots and WSOs in order to assess the level of requirement of 33 cognitive, psychomotor, and perceptual abilities on a Likert-type scale.</excerpt>

affiliations: Flight Operations Training, The Emirates Group, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Human Factors and Aviation, Seeing Machines Limited, Fyshwick, ACT, Australia
title: Eye-Tracking: from Concept to Operational Training Tool
doc: <title>Eye-Tracking: from Concept to Operational Training Tool</title> <excerpt>Eye-tracking has historically been proposed as a tool to provide insight into pilot performance, although its transition from scientific curiosity to a practical device has been challenging. Advancing technology has recently opened the possibility of deploying eye-tracking measurements for operational use in flight training, thus allowing for improved understanding of pilot monitoring strategies. This aims to support a more focused development for both new trainees and experienced pilots in recurrent training.</excerpt>

affiliations: Thales Research and Technology Canada, Quebec, QC, Canada; Toulouse, Toulouse, France
title: Policy Capturing to Support Pilot Decision-Making: A Proof of Concept Study
doc: <title>Policy Capturing to Support Pilot Decision-Making: A Proof of Concept Study</title> <excerpt>Single-pilot operations are cognitively challenging for pilots and could benefit from decision-support tools to mitigate risk-prone situations. The Cognitive Shadow is a prototype tool that employs policy capturing, a data-driven technique used to model decisions, to learn users judgement policies and alert decision discrepancies from one s decision pattern. This proof-of-concept study investigates the potential of policy capturing to model pilots policies facing unstable approaches.</excerpt>

affiliations: The LifeFlight Foundation, Gold Coast, QLD, Australia; School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
title: An Examination of Human Factors in Australian Helicopter Emergency Medical Services (HEMS)
doc: <title>An Examination of Human Factors in Australian Helicopter Emergency Medical Services (HEMS)</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study aims to identify and examine prevalent human factors in the Australian Helicopter Emergency Medical Services (HEMS) industry. Background: There is little research into the human factors of HEMS operations. Weather, fuel planning, fatigue, and pressure are prominent human factors found in HEMS operations globally.</excerpt>

affiliations: Strategic Integration, MITRE Corporation, McLean, VA, United States; Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States; School of Graduate Studies, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States
title: The Technology Readiness and Acceptance Model as a Predictor of Pilots’ Willingness to Operate in UAM Integrated Airspace
doc: <title>The Technology Readiness and Acceptance Model as a Predictor of Pilots’ Willingness to Operate in UAM Integrated Airspace</title> <excerpt>Objective: This research study aimed to identify the factors influencing manned aircraft pilots’ willingness to operate in AAM/UAM integrated airspace using a hypothesized model grounded in the Technology Readiness Index (TRI) and Technology Acceptance Model (TAM). Background: Advanced Air Mobility (AAM) is the concept of using novel aircraft to transport cargo and passengers in and around regional and urban areas. Urban Air Mobility (UAM) is a subset of AAM.</excerpt>

affiliations: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States
title: Qualitative Analysis of General Aviation Pilots’ Aviation Safety Reporting System Incident Narratives Using the Human Factors Analysis and Classification System
doc: <title>Qualitative Analysis of General Aviation Pilots’ Aviation Safety Reporting System Incident Narratives Using the Human Factors Analysis and Classification System</title> <excerpt>NASA's Aviation Safety Reporting System (ASRS) gathers data from voluntary aviation safety reports for nonfatal accidents and incidents. These reports are a valuable resource in identifying unsafe occurrences and hazardous situations in the aviation industry. A tool known as the Human Factors Analysis and Classification System (HFACS), initially developed for military use, has proven useful for root cause analysis of human causes in aviation accidents and incidents, including in commercial contexts.</excerpt>

country: Hong Kong - Korea, Republic of - Macao - Malaysia - United States
affiliations: College of Hospitality and Tourism Management, Sejong University, Seoul, South Korea; College of Human Sciences, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, United States; School of Hotel and Tourism Management, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Department of Food Service and Management, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia; Faculty of Hospitality and Tourism Management, Macau University of Science and Technology, Taipa, Macao
title: COVID-19 and the Airline Business: A New Decision-Making Process for Employee Loyalty and Job Insecurity
doc: <title>COVID-19 and the Airline Business: A New Decision-Making Process for Employee Loyalty and Job Insecurity</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study is designed to present a decision-making process forming airline crews’ loyalty intention to their company, comparing this process before and after the COVID-19 outbreak. Background: Under the threat of COVID-19, the airline industry experienced unprecedented challenging times. Specifically, job security among airline employees was increasingly uncertain.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Mathematics and Systems Analysis, Aalto University, Espoo, Uusimaa, Finland; Department of Military Technology, Finnish National Defence University, Helsinki, Finland; Environment and Computing, Coventry University, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom; Finnish Air Force, Jyvaskyla, Finland
title: Team Performance in Air Combat: A Teamwork Perspective
doc: <title>Team Performance in Air Combat: A Teamwork Perspective</title> <excerpt>Objective: The objective of this paper is to describe a model combining taskwork and teamwork of a single-seat fighter aircraft team, or flight, during its performance episode. Background: In air combat, evaluations of team performance have focused on task performance. However, both teamwork and taskwork are required for high performance output.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aeronautical and Aviation Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
title: The Effects of Aeronautical Decision-Making Models on Student Pilots’ Situational Awareness and Cognitive Workload in Simulated Non-Normal Flight Deck Environment
doc: <title>The Effects of Aeronautical Decision-Making Models on Student Pilots’ Situational Awareness and Cognitive Workload in Simulated Non-Normal Flight Deck Environment</title> <excerpt>Objective: This paper investigates the effects of using different decision-making models on pilots’ performance while facing non-normal flight circumstances. Background: The captain must quickly make appropriate decisions once an aircraft faces emergency. Usually, human error is one primary cause of accidents, which inevitably affects the captain’s decision progress.</excerpt>

affiliations: Environment and Computing, Coventry University, Coventry, West Midlands, United Kingdom
title: It Was This Wing Wasn’t It? Identifying the Importance of Verbal Communication in Aviation Maintenance
doc: <title>It Was This Wing Wasn’t It? Identifying the Importance of Verbal Communication in Aviation Maintenance</title> <excerpt>To place communication in context against other maintenance error promoting contributory factors and identify whether communication issues were written or verbal, a semi-structured interview schedule was used to ask 40 aircraft maintenance personnel what goes wrong when maintaining aircraft. Participants described 746 examples of contributory factors and undesired outcomes which were categorized using Dupont’s “dirty dozen.” 147 of the 746 descriptions were communication factors, of which 99 were verbal, 34 were written and 14 were general. Of 34 verbal and 19 written task miscommunication examples, 22 verbal and 10 written were accompanied by descriptions of undesired outcomes.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aviation and Space Psychology, Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (DLR), Koln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; Department of Social Psychology, Universität Kassel, Kassel, Hessen, Germany; Building Physics, Hochschule für Technik Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany
title: The Relationship between Preparation, Impression Management, and Interview Performance in High-Stakes Personnel Selection: A Field Study of Airline Pilot Applicants
doc: <title>The Relationship between Preparation, Impression Management, and Interview Performance in High-Stakes Personnel Selection: A Field Study of Airline Pilot Applicants</title> <excerpt>Objective: The present study investigates how airline pilot applicants prepare for a personnel selection procedure and how this relates to their deceptive and honest impression management (IM) in the job interview and their interview performance. Background: It is thus far unclear how preparation relates to IM in real-world and high-stakes settings. This is of particular importance for the aviation industry, because numerous commercial providers offer preparation courses for selection procedures potentially impacting selection decisions.</excerpt>

affiliations: School of Aviation, UNSW Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia; The MARCS Institute for Brain, Behaviour and Development, Bankstown, NSW, Australia
title: Miscommunication in Commercial Aviation: The Role of Accent, Speech Rate, Information Density, and Politeness Markers
doc: <title>Miscommunication in Commercial Aviation: The Role of Accent, Speech Rate, Information Density, and Politeness Markers</title> <excerpt>Objective: This study is specifically designed to examine the effect of accent (native or non-native English sounding), rate of speech, complexity of transmission (information density), and politeness markers on commercial pilot (mis)communication. Background: Aviation accident reports often cite miscommunication as a contributing factor. Anecdotal reports from pilots, along with limited empirical studies on pilot communication, further confirm that miscommunication remains a problem.</excerpt>

affiliations: TiER1 Performance Solutions, Covington, KY, United States; Airmen Systems Directorate, Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Integrated Modeling of Fatigue Impacts on C-17 Approach and Landing Performance
doc: <title>Integrated Modeling of Fatigue Impacts on C-17 Approach and Landing Performance</title> <excerpt>Objective: The current effort develops an initial integrated model of fatigue in the context of C-17 approach and landing operations. Specifically, we integrate a biomathematical fatigue model with a task network model to estimate pilot performance degradation. Background: Fatigue risk management is a critical process in aviation and flight deck operations, given its dramatic impact on aviation safety and pilot health.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, United States; Collins Aerospace, Charlotte, NC, United States
title: Towards Human Objective Real-Time Trust of Autonomy Measures for Combat Aviation
doc: <title>Towards Human Objective Real-Time Trust of Autonomy Measures for Combat Aviation</title> <excerpt>Objective: Can objective trust indicators be measured and computed in real time in a within visual range aerial combat “dogfight” scenario consisting of a manned autonomous own-ship versus an adversary? Background: Previous research has focused on human trust of automation during simulated ground combat and human trust of civil aviation automation. Those studies largely consisted of subjective measures of trust analyzed post-hoc. Human trust of autonomy in high-risk situations such as dogfighting had not yet been studied.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Applied Aviation Sciences, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States; Department of Applied Linguistics and TESOL and Assistant Provost, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, United States; G2 Secure Staff, Irving, TX, United States; United Airlines, West Palm Beach, FL, United States; Department of Applied Aviation Sciences, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States
