This study examined the perceived performance of older pilots, if information on ergonomic redesign interventions had a significant effect on attitudes toward ergonomic redesign interventions for older pilots, and how perceived performance and type of information interacted to affect attitudes toward ergonomic redesign interventions for older pilots.</excerpt>

affiliations: Dept. Indust., The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States
title: Automation management strategies: Pilot preferences and operational experiences
doc: <title>Automation management strategies: Pilot preferences and operational experiences</title> <excerpt>With the evolution of technology from passive tool to highly independent agent, it is becoming increasingly important to support operators in coordinating human and machine intentions and actions. One way to achieve this goal is the context-sensitive use and implementation of different automation management strategies. This study examined pilots' preferences for and their operational experiences with 3 different strategies - management-by-consent, management-by-exception, and full automation.</excerpt>

affiliations: College of Engineering, Atlanta, GA, United States
title: Display effects on shaping apparent strategy: A case study in collision detection and avoidance
doc: <title>Display effects on shaping apparent strategy: A case study in collision detection and avoidance</title> <excerpt>This article examines participants' behavior at collision detection and avoidance during parallel approaches and tests how it is affected by additional information on traffic displays. Participant behavior is analyzed by looking for "apparent strategies," measured by characteristics of participants' actions that remain consistent across scenar-ios with strongly different dynamics. The participants' collision detection reactions are found to occur at aircraft lateral separations that are consistent across a variety of scenarios; likewise, collision avoidance maneuvers with a "turn-away" component are consistently chosen for all scenarios.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aerospace Psychology Research Group, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Leinster, Ireland; Brit. Jnl. of Educational Technology, Oxford, United Kingdom; PA Consulting Group, United Kingdom, London, United Kingdom; Department of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Leinster, Ireland
title: An assistant for crew performance assessment
doc: <title>An assistant for crew performance assessment</title> <excerpt>This article describes an airline trial of a prototype personal digital assistant (PDA) intended for use by Check Airmen and Flight or Simulator Instructors. The prototype PDA is capable of electronically recording, storing, and transmitting data in both simulator and airplane across a range of pilot proficiency assessment categories. The background to the trial and our findings are discussed.</excerpt>

affiliations: NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States; NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: Facilitating LOFT debriefings: Instructor techniques and crew participation
doc: <title>Facilitating LOFT debriefings: Instructor techniques and crew participation</title> <excerpt>This study analyzes techniques instructor pilots (IPs) use to facilitate crew analysis and evaluation of line-oriented flight training performance. We analyzed IP facilitation and crew participation for 36 debriefing sessions conducted at 5 U.S. airlines.</excerpt>

affiliations: College of Aeronautics, Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom; College of Aeronautics, Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
title: A psychometric approach to the development of a multidimensional scale to assess aircraft handling qualities
doc: <title>A psychometric approach to the development of a multidimensional scale to assess aircraft handling qualities</title> <excerpt>This article describes the development of a multidimensional scale for the assessment of aircraft handling qualities using psychometric principles. A sample of 141 test pilots completed a structured assessment of their aircraft's handling qualities in 7 common flight maneuvers. From a series of confirmatory factor analyses, 5 stable dimensions of aircraft handling qualities were elicited.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Operations Division, Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia; Air Operations Division, Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia
title: An analysis of slant for guidance of landing approaches
doc: <title>An analysis of slant for guidance of landing approaches</title> <excerpt>For landing without visual aids, judgment of slant angle from texture gradients may be the primary strategy used by pilots to maintain a constant angle of descent toward a runway aimpoint. A mathematical analysis was undertaken to assess whether 1 or more of the available texture gradients have the properties required to support this strategy. The analysis revealed that texture gradients in themselves could not be useful.</excerpt>

affiliations: The Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm, Stockholms, Sweden; Tekniska Fakulteten (Tekniska Högskolan) (LITH), Linkoping, Ostergotlands, Sweden; Centre for Human Factors in Aviation, Tekniska Fakulteten (Tekniska Högskolan) (LITH), Linkoping, Ostergotlands, Sweden
title: Sharing the burden of flight deck automation training
doc: <title>Sharing the burden of flight deck automation training</title> <excerpt>Flight deck automation has generated new training requirements, most of which have been absorbed by in-house airline training, in particular, aircraft transition training. This leaves little room for learning about how human roles have shifted in automated cockpits or how the distinction between technical and nontechnical skills has become blurred when managing the flight path of an automated aircraft. This article explores how overall pilot training quality, efficiency, and effectiveness would benefit from pulling automation training forward into the pilot training curriculum, reducing the burden carried mainly by transition training today.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada
title: Designing functional visualizations for aircraft systems status displays
doc: <title>Designing functional visualizations for aircraft systems status displays</title> <excerpt>A number of researchers have observed that glass cockpit displays tend to be opaque and that this makes it difficult for the flight crew to develop accurate and comprehensive mental models of system functioning, thereby leading to errors in abnormal situations. However, few researchers have suggested how to create better functional visualizations of system behavior, and even fewer have provided examples of what such advanced displays might look like. This article describes how the principles of ecological interface design (EID), a framework developed in the context of process control, can be applied in aviation to design engineering systems status displays.</excerpt>

affiliations: Work and Cognition Laboratory, Université de Toulouse, Toulouse, Occitanie, France; Maison de la Recherche, Université Toulouse - Jean Jaurès, Toulouse, Occitanie, France
title: Datalink communication in flight deck operations: A synthesis of recent studies
doc: <title>Datalink communication in flight deck operations: A synthesis of recent studies</title> <excerpt>Current datalink technology provides alphanumeric messages to aircrews using an air-ground digital link. This system produces a procedural change by modifying the way pilots and air traffic controllers interact. During the last 10 years, many studies have sought to understand and improve pilots' activities and the relationships among controllers and pilots.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, University of Otago, Dunedin, OTA, New Zealand; Department of Social and Preventive Medicine, University of Otago, Dunedin, OTA, New Zealand; Department of Psychology, University of Otago, Dunedin, OTA, New Zealand
title: The incidence of incidents: A nationwide study of flight experience and exposure to accidents and incidents
doc: <title>The incidence of incidents: A nationwide study of flight experience and exposure to accidents and incidents</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; United States Air Force, Arlington, VA, United States; TASC Inc., San Antonio, TX, United States
title: The "outside-in" attitude display concept revisited
doc: <title>The "outside-in" attitude display concept revisited</title> <excerpt>The "outside-in" attitude display concept, which includes a moving-aircraft (as opposed to a moving-horizon) attitude reference, dates back to the early days of flying. The majority of the laboratory and in-flight studies that have evaluated the outside-in format over the years have found it to be superior at preventing roll-reversal errors during normal flying and in recovering from unusual attitudes. Although outside-in attitude displays have been, and continue to be, flown throughout the world, the majority of military and civilian aircraft have failed to adopt this format.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; Veridian, Dayton, OH, United States; Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Development and evaluation of a background attitude indicator
doc: <title>Development and evaluation of a background attitude indicator</title> <excerpt>In this article, we describe a series of 3 studies conducted to evaluate the feasibility of using a unique type of attitude indicator, called a background attitude indicator (BAI), to recover from unusual attitudes. The BAI is a head-down display format that combines tactical information in the central portion of the display with attitude information in the border surrounding the tactical information. The attitude information, in essence, frames the tactics display.</excerpt>

affiliations: Cleveland Clinic Foundation, Cleveland, OH, United States; Department of Aerospace Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States
title: Response predispositions and piloting safety
doc: <title>Response predispositions and piloting safety</title> <excerpt>Aviation safety requires optimization of the human-machine interaction. Although the machine brings great reliability and consistency, human survival has depended on behavioral diversity and ability to adapt to the unexpected. The two approaches, reliability and adaptability, complement each other, but only if the human brings the right adaptive responses to the human-machine interaction.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory, Melbourne, VIC, Australia; Department of Aviation Studies, Western Sydney University, Penrith, NSW, Australia; Department of Aviation Studies, Western Sydney University, Penrith, NSW, Australia
title: Attitudes toward unsafe acts in a sample of Australian general aviation pilots
doc: <title>Attitudes toward unsafe acts in a sample of Australian general aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>The aim of this research was the development and validation of a questionnaire designed to examine attitudes toward unsafe acts that mitigate involvement in human error-related accidents and incidents. A 25-item questionnaire was designed and completed by a sample of 70 pilots in the Australian general aviation industry. The data analysis involved considerations of internal reliability and concurrent validity, in addition to comparisons between experience levels and attendance at human factors seminars.</excerpt>

affiliations: FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States; FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Navigation display design: Displaying nearest airport information
doc: <title>Navigation display design: Displaying nearest airport information</title> <excerpt>Thirty-six participants were tested on their ability to orient toward the nearest airport based on the manner in which information was presented on a global positioning system (GPS) area navigation display. Results indicated that use of the tabular, text-only format normally found on such displays was significantly slower and less accurate than either a map display of nearest airport information or a text display that included an orientation symbol. Additionally, pilots ignored information from the heading indicator, focusing on the GPS to perform the task.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Aviation, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia; College of Liberal Arts & Sciences, Urbana, IL, United States; University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: Transfer of training effectiveness of a personal computer aviation training device
doc: <title>Transfer of training effectiveness of a personal computer aviation training device</title> <excerpt>The training effectiveness of personal computer aviation training devices (PCATDs) has received only limited testing. In the experiment reported here, a commercially available PCATD was evaluated for its transfer effectiveness for teaching of instrument flight skills. Students from the beginning and advanced instrument courses at the University of Illinois were trained to criterion in the PCATD on a wide range of tasks and were then retrained to criterion in the airplane on the same tasks.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Central Michigan University, Mount Pleasant, MI, United States
title: The use of autonomic components to improve cardiovascular assessment of mental workload in flight simulation
doc: <title>The use of autonomic components to improve cardiovascular assessment of mental workload in flight simulation</title> <excerpt>Principal components analysis of multiple psychophysiological measures of cardiovascular activity was used to derive the underlying sympathetic and parasympathetic information needed to represent the autonomic space for heart period. This method was applied to cardiac data that were previously collected during a full-mission flight simulation from volunteer commercial pilots (Corwin et al, 1989). Pilots flew both low-and high-workload mission scenarios in 2 separate test sessions.</excerpt>

affiliations: Professional Performance Improvement Company Dallas, Dallas, TX, United States; Professional Performance Improvement Co., Dallas, TX, United States
title: Conceptual design guidelines to rediscover systems engineering for automated flight decks
doc: <title>Conceptual design guidelines to rediscover systems engineering for automated flight decks</title> <excerpt>An analysis of more than 50 accidents involving automated commercial transport aircraft showed that most of them attributed to pilot error involved reprogramming of automated systems. An examination of current aircraft automation and automation-related training and operations strongly suggests that a major factor in this situation is the lack of adequate systems engineering in the automation development process. An examination of contemporary commercial aircraft systems under guidelines developed in the systems engineering process for an early military terrain-following system reveals weaknesses in the design of the commercial systems.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory, Melbourne, VIC, Australia; Swinburne Computer-Human Interaction Laboratory, Swinburne University of Technology, Hawthorn, VIC, Australia; Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory, Melbourne, VIC, Australia
title: Work domain analysis for training-system definition and acquisition
doc: <title>Work domain analysis for training-system definition and acquisition</title> <excerpt>Training-needs analysis is critical for defining and procuring effective training systems. However, traditional approaches to training-needs analysis are not suitable for capturing the demands of highly automated and computerized work domains. In this article, we propose that work domain analysis can identify the functional structure of a work domain that must be captured in a training system, so that workers can be trained to deal with unpredictable contingencies that cannot be handled by computer systems.</excerpt>

affiliations: Honeywell International Inc., Morris Plains, NJ, United States; Honeywell International Inc., Morris Plains, NJ, United States
title: Shared models of flight management system vertical guidance
doc: <title>Shared models of flight management system vertical guidance</title> <excerpt>Solutions to operational and training issues with flight automation should be based on a complete model of the behaviors of the avionics software shared by pilots, developers, trainers, and human factors researchers. The operational procedure model, described in this article, represents the behavior of the avionics software as a set of intentions associated with situation-action rules. This article focuses on the guidance function incorporated in flight management systems and presents an operational procedure model of vertical guidance..</excerpt>

affiliations: Civil Aeromedical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States; Human Factors Research Lab, FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States
title: Automation in general aviation: Two studies of pilot responses to autopilot malfunctions
doc: <title>Automation in general aviation: Two studies of pilot responses to autopilot malfunctions</title> <excerpt>Study 1 examined 4 automation-related malfunctions (runaway pitch trim up, roll servo failure, roll sensor failure, pitch drift up) and subsequent pilot responses. Study 2 examined 4 additional malfunctions, 2 more immediately obvious (runaway pitch trim down, runaway roll servo) and 2 more subtle (failed attitude indicator, pitch sensor drift down) than those in Study 1, and the effect of an auditory warning. Data collection was performed in the Civil Aeromedical Institute's Advanced General Aviation Research Simulator, configured as a Piper Malibu.</excerpt>

affiliations: CHI Systems Inc, Fort Washington, PA, United States; CHI Systems Inc, Fort Washington, PA, United States
title: The development of specifications for an automated monitoring system interface associated with aircraft condition
doc: <title>The development of specifications for an automated monitoring system interface associated with aircraft condition</title> <excerpt>Because of the complexity and interconnectedness of aircraft subsystems, considerable interpretation is required to determine the implications of conventional system warnings and to decide on the appropriate course of action to ameliorate a fault condition. This article focuses on the case of mechanical fault conditions in rotorcraft. Until recently, only a few simple sensors (eg, oil pressure and temperature, oil debris sensor) were provided to signal mechanical faults.</excerpt>

affiliations: Research Integrations, Inc., Tempe, AZ, United States; Dept. of Indust. and Mfg. Eng., Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR, United States
title: Flight deck automation issues
doc: <title>Flight deck automation issues</title> <excerpt>Although flight deck automation has been well received by pilots and by the aviation industry, many automation human factors issues have been raised. In this study, we surveyed a wide variety of sources, including pilots and other aviation experts; accident reports; incident reports; documentation on other studies of incident reports; and documentation on experiments, surveys, and other studies to identify and compile evidence related to 92 flight deck automation issues. We created a World Wide Web site (http://flightdeck.ie.orst.edu/) to make this information available to the aviation research, development, manufacturing, operational, and regulatory communities..</excerpt>

affiliations: Damos Research Associates, Inc., Los Angeles, CA, United States; Research Integrations, Inc., Tempe, AZ, United States; Damos Research Associates, Inc., Los Angeles, CA, United States
title: The effect of level of automation on time spent looking out of the cockpit
doc: <title>The effect of level of automation on time spent looking out of the cockpit</title> <excerpt>This study examines the effect of level of automation in the cockpit on the proportion of time commercial airline pilots looked out of the cockpit during takeoffs and landings. Data were obtained from 1 model of the B737-200 and 2 models of the B737-300. The B737-200 had an advanced autopilot and traditional instruments.</excerpt>

affiliations: San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States; NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; College of Engineering, Atlanta, GA, United States; NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: Modes in human-machine systems: Constructs, representation, and classification
doc: <title>Modes in human-machine systems: Constructs, representation, and classification</title> <excerpt>This article surveys and discusses human interaction with automated control systems that employ modes. We focus our discussion on the features of the control system that lead to mode confusion and error. We first provide working definitions of the term mode and discuss key constructs that contribute to mode error, such as mode ambiguity and user expectations.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Aviation, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia; Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia
title: Functional interface design for the modern aircraft cockpit
doc: <title>Functional interface design for the modern aircraft cockpit</title> <excerpt>There is an emerging concern that modern glass cockpits induce information overload. This is sometimes thought to be an inevitable result of the increased complexity and the need for automation that accompanies the transition to high technology. We argue here that the human performance problems created by glass cockpits are not an inevitable consequence of increased hardware complexity or of automation but, instead, are a result of nonfunctional design that increases complexity at the cockpit interface.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States; Aerospace Crew Research Project, Austin, TX, United States
title: The evolution of crew resource management training in commercial aviation
doc: <title>The evolution of crew resource management training in commercial aviation</title> <excerpt>In this study, we describe changes in the nature of Crew Resource Management (CRM) training in commercial aviation, including its shift from cockpit to crew resource management. Validation of the impact of CRM is discussed. Limitations of CRM, including lack of cross-cultural generality are considered.</excerpt>

affiliations: Université Toulouse - Jean Jaurès, Toulouse, Occitanie, France; Work and Cognition Laboratory, Université Toulouse - Jean Jaurès, Toulouse, Occitanie, France
title: Temporal management of flight strips in en route air traffic control: A full-scope simulation test on task analyses assumptions
doc: <title>Temporal management of flight strips in en route air traffic control: A full-scope simulation test on task analyses assumptions</title> <excerpt>In en route air traffic control, task analyses assume that the planning controller detects potential problems to alleviate the radar controller's workload. Ten expert controllers were involved in a full-scope simulation study, and displacements of flight strips were analyzed as a function of the controller and as a function of the role these motor acts have in indicating problem detection, monitoring the ongoing resolution, or sending the aircraft to other control positions. Task analysis assumptions related to the ongoing resolution and to the end of problems were confirmed.</excerpt>

affiliations: Netherlands Aerospace Centre NLR, Amsterdam, Noord-Holland, Netherlands; Man-Machine Integration Department, Netherlands Aerospace Centre NLR, Amsterdam, Noord-Holland, Netherlands
title: An experimental comparison of alphanumeric and iconic formats of the Flight Mode annunciator
doc: <title>An experimental comparison of alphanumeric and iconic formats of the Flight Mode annunciator</title> <excerpt>An iconic alternative was designed for the conventional alphanumeric Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) display. The two FMA types were compared in three experiments. In the first experiment, participants had to recall an FMA display that was presented for a short period of time.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States; Department of Psychology, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States
title: Evidence for the validity of PC-based simulations in studying aircrew coordination
doc: <title>Evidence for the validity of PC-based simulations in studying aircrew coordination</title> <excerpt>Recently, advances in computer technology have allowed the use of PC-based simulations for a variety of aviation training and research purposes. One area in particular where PC-based simulations have been used extensively is the study of aircrew coordination. Yet, there have always been lingering questions about the validity of these simulations.</excerpt>

affiliations: Summit Technologies, Inc., Orlando, FL, United States; Naval Air Warfare Center - Training Systems Division, Orlando, FL, United States; Naval Air Warfare Center, Orlando, FL, United States
title: Event-based approach to training (EBAT)
doc: <title>Event-based approach to training (EBAT)</title> <excerpt>The importance of providing real-world experience through virtual environments is well accepted, and this mode of training is used extensively in aviation. It is, therefore, surprising that there are few general methods that guide the design of simulation-based training. The lack of such methods is problematic.</excerpt>

affiliations: Center for Applied Human Factors in Aviation, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States; FlightSafety Int, Daytona Beach, FL, United States; University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States
title: Personal computer-based flight training devices
doc: <title>Personal computer-based flight training devices</title> <excerpt>This article reviews the role of personal computer aviation training devices (PCATDs) in general aviation pilot training. A brief history of flight simulator development is provided, accompanied by a sampling of early research on the effectiveness of simulator training. PCATDs are described along with their more common interface devices.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Applied Psychology, Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom; Department of Applied Psychology, Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
title: Computer-based simulation as an adjunct to Ab initio flight training
doc: <title>Computer-based simulation as an adjunct to Ab initio flight training</title> <excerpt>Two groups of ab initio student pilots were given training on a flight simulation package running on a desk-top computer prior to performing some basic flight maneuvers in the air. One group interacted with the computer using a representative set of flight controls. The other group used only the computer's cursor and function keys.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Evaluating the effectiveness of flight simulators for training combat skills: A review
doc: <title>Evaluating the effectiveness of flight simulators for training combat skills: A review</title> <excerpt>The military is focusing a great deal of effort on developing virtual world technologies that will allow training combat skills in flight simulators. Considerably less attention is being directed toward documenting the effectiveness of such training. In this article, we review Air Force and Navy efforts to evaluate the effectiveness of training the combat skills necessary for attack and fighter aircraft in flight simulators.</excerpt>

affiliations: Volpe National Transportation System Center, Cambridge, MA, United States; Federal Aviation Administration, Washington, D.C., United States; Volpe National Transportation System Center, Cambridge, MA, United States
title: Simulator platform motion - The need revisited
doc: <title>Simulator platform motion - The need revisited</title> <excerpt>The need to provide increased access to flight simulator training for U.S. regional airlines, which historically have been limited by cost considerations in the use of such equipment for pilot recurrent training, is discussed in this article. In light of that need, the issue of whether more affordable fixed-base simulators, identical to full flight simulators in all respects except for absence of platform motion, might provide an equivalent level of safety when employed for recurrent training is examined.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Education Training Professional, Pensacola, FL, United States; Department of the Navy, NETPDTC, Pensacola, FL, United States
title: Predicting naval aviator flight training performance using multiple regression and an artificial neural network
doc: <title>Predicting naval aviator flight training performance using multiple regression and an artificial neural network</title> <excerpt>The potential of a series of automated single-task and multitask tests to account for additional significant variance in the prediction of Navy pilot flight grades was evaluated. Volunteer participants (student naval aviators) were tested on a series of cognitive and perceptual psychomotor tests. The participants then entered the Navy's flight training program at Whiting Field, Florida.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, The University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK, United States; FAA Civil Aerospace Medical Institute, Oklahoma City, OK, United States; Department of Psychology, The University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK, United States
title: En route operational errors and situation awareness
doc: <title>En route operational errors and situation awareness</title> <excerpt>En route operational errors that occurred during 1993 were analyzed to determine if controllers who were aware that an error was developing differed from unaware controllers in the type and severity of errors they made. Neither the personnel nor the air traffic situation distinguished "aware" from "unaware" controllers. However, unaware controllers were more likely to commit certain technical and cognitive mistakes.</excerpt>

affiliations: Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia; Department of Computer Engineering, RMIT University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia; Defence Science and Technology Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia
title: A mathematical model of glide-slope perception in the visual approach to landing
doc: <title>A mathematical model of glide-slope perception in the visual approach to landing</title> <excerpt>A mathematical model of glide-slope perception is presented for the visual approach to landing when there is a visually impoverished scene. The perceptual process has been modeled as the weighted average of the geometric relations in the scene that provide glide-slope information, with weights being adjusted during the approach to minimize the uncertainty in glide-slope perception. The model suggests that the optimum combination of relations providing glide-slope information is dependent on the range from the runway threshold and that there is a relation between the handling qualities of aircraft or flight simulators and the adjustment of the weights..</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Labor Studies, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv-Yafo, Tel Aviv District, Israel
title: Coordination in the cockpit: A game-theory view of standard operation procedures
doc: <title>Coordination in the cockpit: A game-theory view of standard operation procedures</title> <excerpt>Some basic principles of game theory confirm that flying according to standard operating procedures (SOP) leads to greater flight safety. In this article, the interaction in the cockpit is analyzed as a game whose goal is flight safety. The crew members are involved in interactions that determine the extent of their utility.</excerpt>

affiliations: Logicon Inc., Torrance, CA, United States; Crew System Interface Division, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Dayton, OH, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Computer modeling of operator mental workload and situational awareness in simulated air-to-ground combat: An assessment of predictive validity
doc: <title>Computer modeling of operator mental workload and situational awareness in simulated air-to-ground combat: An assessment of predictive validity</title> <excerpt>The predictive validity of computer modeling of operator mental workload and situational awareness during a simulated air-to-ground combat mission was assessed. In Phase 1 of the study, 12 participants completed a series of simulated flights and provided Subjective Workload Assessment Technique (SWAT) ratings of workload and Situational Awareness Rating Technique (SART) ratings of situational awareness. In Phase 2, computer models of the combat mission were constructed using the Micro Saint modeling tool.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aviation Research Laboratory, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Honeywell Technology Center, Minneapolis, MN, United States
title: Head-up displays: Effects of clutter, display intensity, and display location on pilot performance
doc: <title>Head-up displays: Effects of clutter, display intensity, and display location on pilot performance</title> <excerpt>Two experiments examined the effects of display location (head-up and head-down), display clutter, and display intensity on pilot performance in a general aviation-cruise flight environment. In Experiment 1, a low-fidelity simulation revealed that the detection of commanded flight changes and flight-path tracking performance was better in the head-down condition as compared to the head-up condition. In contrast, midair traffic detection was superior with the head-up display (HUD), reflecting an attentional trade-off.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Polish Air Force Institute of Aviation Medicine, Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland; Department of Psychology, Polish Air Force Institute of Aviation Medicine, Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland
title: Oculographic assessment of workload influence on flight performance
doc: <title>Oculographic assessment of workload influence on flight performance</title> <excerpt>Presented are specific parameters of visual information intake in pilots on the job. The role of eye movements in the process of visual stimulus reception is discussed. Our own study on a MIG-23 flight simulator is presented.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, UiT Norges Arktiske Universitet, Tromso, Troms Og Finnmark, Norway
title: Pilot selection in the Norwegian Air Force: A validation and meta-analysis of the test battery
doc: <title>Pilot selection in the Norwegian Air Force: A validation and meta-analysis of the test battery</title> <excerpt>The purpose of this study was to evaluate the test battery currently used for pilot selection to the Norwegian Air Force. Selection is currently based on a standard battery of 20 different psychological tests as well as on medical tests and on an interview by a licensed psychologist. First, two-factor analyses were conducted to examine the relation between the tests in the battery.</excerpt>

affiliations: Université Polytechnique Hauts-de-France, Valenciennes, Hauts-de-France, France
title: Cognitive evaluation of human-human and human-machine cooperation modes in air traffic control
doc: <title>Cognitive evaluation of human-human and human-machine cooperation modes in air traffic control</title> <excerpt>An experiment is described that aimed at evaluating a principle of dynamic task allocation (DTA) of conflict resolution between aircraft in air-traffic control on a large scale simulator. It included three cognitive agents: the radar controller (RC), in charge of conflict detection and resolution; the planning controller (PC), in charge of entry-exit coordination and of workload regulation; and a conflict resolution computer system (SAINTEX), able to manage only simple conflicts. Within this three-agent paradigm, three conditions were compared: (a) a control condition (without computer assistance); (b) an explicit condition (PC and RC in charge of the allocation); and (c) an assisted explicit condition (SAINTEX proposed allocations which could be changed by PC).</excerpt>

affiliations: San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States; University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, United States; Western Aerospace Labs, NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; Department of Psychology, San Francisco State University, San Francisco, CA, United States
title: Automation bias: Decision making and performance in high-tech cockpits
doc: <title>Automation bias: Decision making and performance in high-tech cockpits</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aviation Studies, Western Sydney University, Penrith, NSW, Australia
title: A computer-based analysis of expert and novice flight instructor preflight decision making
doc: <title>A computer-based analysis of expert and novice flight instructor preflight decision making</title> <excerpt>The study was designed to examine aspects of flight instructor decision making involving the decision to authorize a student to conduct an initial, solo, cross-country flight. Experienced and inexperienced flight instructors were examined on a number of dimensions during a computer-based task presented in a Windows-based environment. Although differences were noted between experienced and inexperienced flight instructors in terms of the decision-outcome, no differences were evident relating to the process of information acquisition.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Aviation, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Center for Applied Human Factors in Aviation, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States; Aviation Research Laboratory, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: Transfer and quasi-transfer effects of scene detail and visual augmentation in landing training
doc: <title>Transfer and quasi-transfer effects of scene detail and visual augmentation in landing training</title> <excerpt>Beginning flight students were taught landings in a flight simulator with a visual landing display to examine the effects of scene detail, visual augmented guidance, and number of landing training trials. Some students were trained in a control condition with no visual display. Transfer was assessed in the airplane in relation to the amount of landing training required prior to release for solo.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Department of Industrial Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; 302 Whittemore Hall, Virginia Tech College of Engineering, Blacksburg, VA, United States
title: Visual and auditory localization as a function of azimuth and elevation
doc: <title>Visual and auditory localization as a function of azimuth and elevation</title> <excerpt>This study was performed to investigate the accuracy of performing a localization task as a function of the use of three display formats: auditory, perspective, and combined perspective-auditory. The experimental task for the perspective and perspective-auditory displays was to judge the relative azimuth and elevation that separated a computer-generated target object from a reference object. The experimental task for the auditory display was to determine the azimuth and elevation of a sound source with respect to the listener.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Rucker, AL, United States; U.S. Army Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Novosel, AL, United States
title: Effectiveness of institutionalized countermeasures on crew rest during rapid transitions from daytime to nighttime flying
doc: <title>Effectiveness of institutionalized countermeasures on crew rest during rapid transitions from daytime to nighttime flying</title> <excerpt>Aircrews frequently experience sleep loss when working rapidly rotating flight schedules. This study evaluated the efficacy of crew rest maintenance policies implemented by a school of aviation. After night flights, pilots living at home experienced daily reductions in sleep time, whereas pilots living under the school's regulations maintained equivalent sleep durations after day and night flights.</excerpt>

affiliations: RMS Information Systems, Inc., Lanham, MD, United States; RMS Information Systems, Gaithersburg, MD, United States
title: Evaluating controller communication time as a measure of workload
doc: <title>Evaluating controller communication time as a measure of workload</title> <excerpt>The duration time that an en route controller is actively engaged in ground-to-air communications has been investigated to determine if the duration is a valid measure of controller workload. Data was collected during a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Planned View Display Baseline Study conducted with Washington Air Route Traffic Control Center personnel. The correlation coefficient between the controllers' communication duration of the 4 min prior to a rating and the controllers' real-time subjective workload ratings was r = .88, p < .01, which validates communication duration as a workload measure.</excerpt>

affiliations: United States Navy, Norfolk, VA, United States; University of North Florida, Jacksonville, FL, United States; U.S. Naval Safety Center, Norfolk, VA, United States
title: A human error approach to accident investigation: The taxonomy of unsafe operations
doc: <title>A human error approach to accident investigation: The taxonomy of unsafe operations</title> <excerpt>Human error continues to be implicated in the vast majority of aviation accidents. Yet, most accident investigation and reporting systems are not currently designed around any theoretical framework of human error. One reason may be the discontinuity between classical theories of human error and the practical application of these theoretical approaches in accident investigation.</excerpt>

affiliations: Atlantic City International Airport, William J. Hughes Technical Center, Atlantic City, NJ, United States
title: Mental models and situation awareness in air traffic control
doc: <title>Mental models and situation awareness in air traffic control</title> <excerpt>Air traffic controllers report that they form a mental picture of aircraft in airspace to assist in their work. In this study, the relationship of the picture to the concepts of mental models and situation awareness (SA) is discussed. A definition of SA is proposed that suggests it is the transient contents of awareness, as structured and supported by an underlying mental model.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Auckland, AUK, New Zealand
title: Symptoms of fatigue and coping strategies in international pilots
doc: <title>Symptoms of fatigue and coping strategies in international pilots</title> <excerpt>Fatigue is a major problem for international aircrew flying transmeridian routes. One hundred eighty-eight international pilots responded to a questionnaire that assessed overall fatigue and the symptoms pilots associated with fatigue on duty. The questionnaire also assessed the methods used by pilots to cope with fatigue before a duty as well as on the flight deck.</excerpt>

affiliations: Rotary Wing Aviation Research Unit, Fort Rucker, AL, United States; Rotary Wing Aviation Research Unit, Fort Rucker, AL, United States
title: The effects of the AH-64A pilot's night vision system on the performance of seven simulated maneuver tasks
doc: <title>The effects of the AH-64A pilot's night vision system on the performance of seven simulated maneuver tasks</title> <excerpt>The Pilot's Night Vision System (PNVS) allows the pilot of the AH-64A Apache helicopter to fly and navigate effectively at night. The PNVS restricts field of view (FOV) and degrades visual acuity, two factors that should adversely affect pilot performance during night operations, especially for flight maneuvers that rely on peripheral cues. Participants, all AH-64A instructor pilots, flew a mission profile in a high-fidelity simulation of the AH-64A.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of North Florida, Jacksonville, FL, United States; United States Navy, Norfolk, VA, United States; Department of Psychology, University of North Florida, Jacksonville, FL, United States
title: Human factors analysis of postaccident data: Applying theoretical taxonomies of human error
doc: <title>Human factors analysis of postaccident data: Applying theoretical taxonomies of human error</title> <excerpt>Human error is involved in nearly all aviation accidents, yet most accident reporting systems are not currently designed around any theoretical human-error framework. As a result, subsequent postaccident databases generally are not conducive to traditional human factors analysis, making the identification of interventions extremely difficult. To address this issue, this study utilized 3 conceptual models of information processing and human error to reorganize the human factors database associated with U.S.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, United States; Man-Vehicle Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
title: Optic flow and visual analysis of the base-to-final turn
doc: <title>Optic flow and visual analysis of the base-to-final turn</title> <excerpt>In the spirit of other optic flow research, we address the problem of how a pilot turns an airplane into alignment with a runway, a maneuver that is one of the more challenging phases of visually controlled flight. In earlier work, Loomis and Beall (1992) proposed a rule for turning an aircraft into alignment: Turn the aircraft in such a way as to hold constant the rate of change of splay (the angle the projected runway makes with respect to the vertical). The experiment presented in this article was a psychophysical test of this rule.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Rucker, AL, United States; Aeromedical Factors Branch, U.S. Army Aeromedical Research Laboratory, Fort Novosel, AL, United States
title: Sustaining female helicopter pilot performance with Dexedrine® during sleep deprivation
doc: <title>Sustaining female helicopter pilot performance with Dexedrine® during sleep deprivation</title> <excerpt>To investigate the efficacy of Dexedrine® for maintaining the performance of sleep deprived female aviators, 6 female UH-60 pilots were exposed to 2 40-hr sleep deprivation periods during which they alternately received Dexedrine® (3 10-mg doses) or placebo. Dexedrine improved 6 of 9 flight simulator maneuvers and enhanced general levels of alertness as measured by EEG and Profile of Mood States assessments. The results from a cognitive test were negligible and inconsistent, probably because of the short test duration.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Huntsville, AL, United States; Department of Psychology, Huntsville, AL, United States
title: Alarm reaction patterns by pilots as a function of reaction modality
doc: <title>Alarm reaction patterns by pilots as a function of reaction modality</title> <excerpt>Past research has demonstrated that operators may lose faith in an alarm system that they deem unreliable. This cry-wolf effect is manifested by slower and less frequent alarm responses. This research examined the effect of reaction modality (manual or vocal) on reactions to alarms of moderate reliability.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg, Gauteng, South Africa
title: Deliberate decision making by aircraft pilots: A simple reminder to avoid decision making under panic
doc: <title>Deliberate decision making by aircraft pilots: A simple reminder to avoid decision making under panic</title> <excerpt>The problem of poor decision making by pilots has been identified clearly as a significant contributor to aviation accidents. Various programs have been developed to address the problem and are being applied, principally in ab initio pilot training. International airlines and military aviation authorities have developed their own programs.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Aviation, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Aviation Research Laboratory, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: Electronic map evaluation in simulated visual meteorological conditions
doc: <title>Electronic map evaluation in simulated visual meteorological conditions</title> <excerpt>This study examined the effects of planar versus perspective electronic map displays during a simulated visual approach to landing. Thirty pilots were divided into 3 groups of 10 and assigned to 1 of 3 display conditions: 2-dimensional, 3-dimensional, or a 2-dimensional condition augmented with a "wedge" to provide a visual momentum between the display view and that in the forward field of view. Each display condition was manipulated in terms of frame of reference, either rotating track-up or fixed north-up, and assessments were made of the pilots' ability to maintain the flight path and awareness of surrounding terrain.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, United States
title: Distributed representation as a principle for the analysis of cockpit information displays
doc: <title>Distributed representation as a principle for the analysis of cockpit information displays</title> <excerpt>This article examines the representational properties of cockpit information displays from the perspective of distributed representations (Zhang & Norman, 1994). The basic idea is that the information needed for many tasks in a cockpit is distributed across the external information displays in the cockpit and the internal minds of the pilots. It is proposed that the relative distribution of internal and external information is the major factor of a display's representational efficiency.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Air Warfare Center - Training Systems Division, Orlando, FL, United States; University of Colorado Denver, Denver, CO, United States; Naval Air Warfare Center, Aviation Team Training Laboratory, Orlando, FL, United States
title: The role of trainee knowledge structures in aviation team environments
doc: <title>The role of trainee knowledge structures in aviation team environments</title> <excerpt>The importance of having well-developed knowledge structures to enhance complex team performance has been recently indicated in the training effectiveness literature. This work tested that proposition within an aviation team training setting. Results suggested that aviation team training improved the knowledge structures of those participants who received the training.</excerpt>

affiliations: People Technologies, Twickenham, United Kingdom
title: Large sample validations of three general predictors of pilot training success
doc: <title>Large sample validations of three general predictors of pilot training success</title> <excerpt>This article addresses one of the perennial problems of pilot selection research: obtaining an adequate sample size for reliable statistical analysis of predictive validity. Results from three studies involving the same computerized tests of instrument comprehension and psychomotor ability were combined in a meta-analysis to determine whether the validities of these tests generalized across three contexts. These were Royal Air Force and Turkish Air Force fixed-wing pilot training and British Army Air Corps rotary-wing pilot training.</excerpt>

affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States; Department of Psychology, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, United States
title: National culture and flight Deck automation: Results of a multination survey
doc: <title>National culture and flight Deck automation: Results of a multination survey</title> <excerpt>Attitudes regarding flight deck automation were surveyed in a sample of 5,879 airline pilots from 12 nations. The average difference in endorsement levels across 11 items for pilots flying automated aircraft in 12 nations was 53%, reflecting significant national differences in attitudes on all items, with the largest differences observed for preference and enthusiasm for automation. The range of agreement across nations was on average four times larger than the range of agreement across different airlines within the same nation, and roughly six times larger than the range across pilots of standard and pilots of automated aircraft.</excerpt>

affiliations: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States; Vermont Alcohol Research Center, Colchester, VT, United States; Ctr. for Aviation/Aerospace Research, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, United States
title: Methodological Issues in Research on the Effects of Alcohol on Pilot Performance
doc: <title>Methodological Issues in Research on the Effects of Alcohol on Pilot Performance</title> <excerpt>The effects of low blood-alcohol levels on pilot performance have been found to be surprisingly inconsistent, given the variety of cognitive, attentional, and motor coordination processes involved in piloting tasks and the presumed susceptibility of these processes to alcohol. Discussed in this article are a number of methodological issues that are relevant to research in this area, including task and subject characteristics, compensation for alcohol effects, and experimental design procedure considerations. Such factors may complicate attempts to determine the relationship between blood-alcohol levels and pilot performance and lead to an underestimation of alcohol effects..</excerpt>

affiliations: Distributed Systems Department; Performance Engineering Department, Household Credit Services, Salinas, CA, United States; Dept. of Indust. and Mfg. Eng., Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR, United States; Indust. and Mfg. Engineering, Boston, MA, United States
title: Studies of cockpit task management errors
doc: <title>Studies of cockpit task management errors</title> <excerpt>Cockpit task management (CTM) is the management level activity pilots perform as they initiate, monitor, prioritize, and terminate cockpit tasks. To better understand the nature and significance of this process, we conducted 3 empirical studies: a review of National Transportation Safety Board aircraft accident reports, a review of Aviation Safety Reporting System aircraft incident reports, and a simulator experiment. In the accident report study, we determined that CTM errors occurred in 76 (23%) of the 324 accidents we reviewed.</excerpt>

affiliations: Systems Research Laboratories, Air Force Materiel Command, Dayton, OH, United States; Air Force Materiel Command, Dayton, OH, United States; c/o AL/CFTO, Air Force Materiel Command, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Do individuals' visual recognition thresholds predict performance on concurrent attitude control flight tasks?
doc: <title>Do individuals' visual recognition thresholds predict performance on concurrent attitude control flight tasks?</title> <excerpt>Two experiments tested near-threshold recognition performance throughout the visual field, examined the effect of the recognition task on a concurrent attitude tracking task, and tested whether individuals' near-threshold performance would predict their dual-task performance. In Experiment 1, an adaptive procedure measured the minimum viewing duration necessary for 75% performance in an aircraft classification task at various nonfoveal locations. Participants' critical tracking ability was also assessed using a central attitude display.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Force Materiel Command, Dayton, OH, United States; Department of Management and Finance, Indiana State University, Terre Haute, IN, United States
title: Predicting with logistic or linear regression: Will it make a difference in who is selected for pilot training?
doc: <title>Predicting with logistic or linear regression: Will it make a difference in who is selected for pilot training?</title> <excerpt>Selecting individuals for pilot training is typically accomplished by determining what human characteristics are predictive of training success using ordinary linear regression. Frequently, however, the measure of success is passing or failing training. Some critics suggest that ordinary linear regression is inappropriate for such a dichotomous criterion and recommend using logistic regression.</excerpt>

affiliations: Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Department of Psychology, University of Hull, Hull, East Yorkshire, United Kingdom
title: Validation of the Cathay Pacific airways pilot selection program
doc: <title>Validation of the Cathay Pacific airways pilot selection program</title> <excerpt>This article reports the validation of the Cathay Pacific ab initio, second (S/O) and first officer (F/O) pilot recruitment systems, using performance ratings from operational base and line checks as criteria for the S/O and F/O entrants, and grading and training outcome as criteria for the ab initio entrants. Good levels of prediction are found for the ab initio training course. Higher levels of prediction are found for operational criteria for the S/Os than for the F/Os.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States; Aviation Research Laboratory, Univ. of Illinois-Willard Airport, IL, United States
title: Electronic maps for terminal area navigation: Effects of frame of reference and dimensionality
doc: <title>Electronic maps for terminal area navigation: Effects of frame of reference and dimensionality</title> <excerpt>Two experiments are reported that contrast rotating versus fixed electronic map displays, which pilots used for a simulated approach to a landing. In Experiment 1, a rotating versus fixed-map display was experimentally crossed with a two-dimensional (2D) versus three-dimensional (3D) view (perspective map) as pilots' ability to maintain the flight path and demonstrate awareness of the location of surrounding terrain features were assessed. Rotating displays supported better flight path guidance and did not substantially harm performance on terrain awareness tasks.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Wright State University, Dayton, OH, United States; Department of Mathematics and Statistics, Wright State University, Dayton, OH, United States; Department of Psychology, Wright State University, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Boundaries of cognitive performance as a function of age and flight experience
doc: <title>Boundaries of cognitive performance as a function of age and flight experience</title> <excerpt>Age and expertise effects on time-sharing performance were examined. Pilots were considered to have an expertise in time-sharing because of their cockpit experience. Ninety pilots and nonpilots performed a battery of cognitive tasks that represented different aspects of piloting.</excerpt>

affiliations: Logicon Inc., Torrance, CA, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States; Logicon Inc., Torrance, CA, United States
title: Target detection performance in helmet-mounted and conventional dome displays
doc: <title>Target detection performance in helmet-mounted and conventional dome displays</title> <excerpt>An experiment was conducted to assess visual target detection performance using a helmet-mounted display (HMD) and a conventional flight simulation dome display. Measures of workload and mood were also obtained. Participants in both viewing conditions scanned an area 120° vertical by 240° horizontal while attempting to locate targets that appeared to be approaching them from one of a possible 18 locations.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Aerospace Medical Research Laboratory, Pensacola, FL, United States; Department of Psychology, University of North Florida, Jacksonville, FL, United States
title: Methamphetamine effects on cognitive processing during extended wakefulness
doc: <title>Methamphetamine effects on cognitive processing during extended wakefulness</title> <excerpt>We examined the effects of both 5- and 10-mg/70 kg body weight of d-methamphetamine HCl on high event rate vigilance and tracking performance in a 13.5-hr sustained-performance session during one night of sleep loss. At 0116 hours, participants were administered either a 5 mg/70 kg oral dose of d-methamphetamine (n = 10), 10 mg/70 kg d-methamphetamine (n = 10), or a placebo (n = 10) using standard double-blind procedures. Performance on all measures degraded markedly during the night in the placebo group.</excerpt>

affiliations: Human Factors Group, University of Dayton Research Institute, Dayton, OH, United States; Mail Station El 10, Delphi, Troy, MI, United States
title: Assessing the influence of operational factors on the perceived structure of real-world scenes viewed during low-altitude, high-speed flight
doc: <title>Assessing the influence of operational factors on the perceived structure of real-world scenes viewed during low-altitude, high-speed flight</title> <excerpt>Previous research indicates that pilots of most jet-fighter aircraft attend to similar elements of the natural flight environment when flying at low altitudes. However, some evidence suggests that differences may exist for pilots of certain specific types of aircraft. The present experiment examined the influence of operational factors on the perceived structure of real-world scenes viewed during low-altitude flight.</excerpt>

affiliations: The Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm, Stockholms, Sweden
title: The Aircraft Crash at Gottröra: Experiences of the Cockpit Crew
doc: <title>The Aircraft Crash at Gottröra: Experiences of the Cockpit Crew</title> <excerpt>This article deals with an aircraft accident in which the two engines lost their power immediately after takeoff and the pilots succeeded in landing the aircraft safely with the 129 people on board. The pilots have been interviewed concerning the human machine interaction, the task allocation, and their reactions. The theoretical background relates to Reason's (1990) theory on human errors lis well as to Wicken's (1994) analysis of automation-induced problems.</excerpt>

affiliations: Calspan Corporation, Buffalo, NY, United States; Veda Inc, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Lessons Learned in Applying Simulators to Crewstation Evaluation
doc: <title>Lessons Learned in Applying Simulators to Crewstation Evaluation</title> <excerpt>As crewstations have become more sophisticated, crewstation designers have tried to evaluate them earlier in their development (to minimize design changes) and in simulators (to minimize evaluation costs). However, selecting the simulator lo use during evaluation is driven more by simulator usage costs and availability than by an analysis of the simulator features needed for an effective crcwslation evaluation. This problem stems in part from a lack of well-documented lessons learned in identifying which simulator features are required to produce the same results as those obtained in flight.</excerpt>

affiliations: Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
title: Effectiveness of Ab Initio Flight Training Using Either Linked or Unlinked Primary-Axis Flight Controls
doc: <title>Effectiveness of Ab Initio Flight Training Using Either Linked or Unlinked Primary-Axis Flight Controls</title> <excerpt>Twenty ab initio student pilots flew a scries of simulated approaches in either a linked or unlinked primary flight control configuration The results indicated that those pilots who performed the task in the unlinked configuration flew less smoothly than those in the linked condition and showed no evidence of skill acquisition, it is suggested that the physical linkage of the student's and instructor's primary flight controls is an important channel of communication that enhances skill development in trainee pilots. © 1995, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved..</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States
title: Situation Awareness as a Function of Frame of Reference, Computer-Graphics Eyepoint Elevation, and Geometric Field of View
doc: <title>Situation Awareness as a Function of Frame of Reference, Computer-Graphics Eyepoint Elevation, and Geometric Field of View</title> <excerpt>The purpose olthis study was lo determine how 3 variable for the design of a “heads-down” spatial display—the frame rrf reference (pilot's eye vs God's eye). geomrtric field of view, and elevation of the computer graphics eye-point—influenced situation awareness. Thirteen flight-naive suhjrcts each flew u simulated F-16 over a computer-generated flight environment lo lock onto and intercept a series or sequelitially appearing targets.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, United States; NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States
title: Quantitative Measurement of Observed Workload in the Analysis of Aircrew Performance
doc: <title>Quantitative Measurement of Observed Workload in the Analysis of Aircrew Performance</title> <excerpt>A methodology for the quantitative evaluation of observed workload was proposed. The model was designed to provide point estimations of observed workload at any time during the performance of a set of tasks. The model was also designed to provide information about the task-scheduling strategies used to complete a set of tasks.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States; Naval Air Warfare Center - Training Systems Division, Orlando, FL, United States
title: Impact of Automation on Aircrew Communication and Decision-Making Performance
doc: <title>Impact of Automation on Aircrew Communication and Decision-Making Performance</title> <excerpt>Increasing levels of automation are being introduced into the cockpit. Yet, it is difficult to predict the impact of these automatic systems on other elements of flight, such as crew communication and the ability to arrive at an effective decision. This study attempted to clarify the relation among these variables.</excerpt>

affiliations: Rowan College of New Jersey, Glassboro, NJ, United States
title: Peripheral Target Recognition and Visual Field Narrowing in Aviators and Nonaviators
doc: <title>Peripheral Target Recognition and Visual Field Narrowing in Aviators and Nonaviators</title> <excerpt>In the two experiments that examined recognition accuracy in the near visual periphery as a function of foveal cognitive load, aviators were shown to have larger effective functional visual fields than nonaviators. The aviators appeared to be far less susceptible to the visual field narrowing found in nonaviators. The narrowing found in nonaviators suggested a tunnel-vision-like pattern.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Minnesota Twin Cities, Minneapolis, MN, United States
title: Performance, Workload, and Fatigue Changes Associated With Automation
doc: <title>Performance, Workload, and Fatigue Changes Associated With Automation</title> <excerpt>The experiments discussed in this article addressed the influence of part-task automation on operator performance, workload, and fatigue in a multitask environment. The overall task environment included tracking, resource management, and multiple monitoring subtasks. Slower, more accurate monitoring and better resource management were observed when the tracking subtask was automated.</excerpt>

affiliations: Western Aerospace Labs, NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; University of Minnesota Twin Cities, Minneapolis, MN, United States
title: Special Issue Editorial
doc: <title>Special Issue Editorial</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Dayton, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Some Measurement and Methodological Considerations in the Application of Subjective Workload Measurement Techniques
doc: <title>Some Measurement and Methodological Considerations in the Application of Subjective Workload Measurement Techniques</title> <excerpt>Previous research with the NASA Task Load Index (TLX) and the Subjective Workload Assessment Technique (SWAT) has demonstrated their sensitivity to variations in workload under flight and other complex work conditions but has not addressed some important measurement and methodological issues regarding their application. This article reviews data that address several such issues including the effects of delayed workload ratings, the effects of previous workload levels on ratings, and procedures used to combine subscale ratings into one overall estimate of subjective workload. © 1995, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.</excerpt>

affiliations: Institute of Aviation, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: Role of Multiple Resources in Predicting Time-Sharing Efficiency: Evaluation of Three Workload Models in a Multiple-Task Setting
doc: <title>Role of Multiple Resources in Predicting Time-Sharing Efficiency: Evaluation of Three Workload Models in a Multiple-Task Setting</title> <excerpt>The goal of our study was to assess the validity of the assumptions underlying three prominent workload models: the Time-Line Analysis and Prediction workload model (Parks & Boucek, 1989), the VACP workload model (Aldrich, Szabo, & Bierbaum, 1989), and the W/INDEX model (North & Riley, 1989). Sixteen subjects flew a low-fidelity flight simulation. Subjects were required to perform a two-axis tracking task, a concurrent visual-monitoring task, and a discrete decision task.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Minnesota Twin Cities, Minneapolis, MN, United States; University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Japan, Kitakyushu, Fukuoka, Japan
title: Influence of Task Demand Characteristics on Workload and Performance
doc: <title>Influence of Task Demand Characteristics on Workload and Performance</title> <excerpt>Two experiments are reported that examined the influence of variation in task demand on performance and workload. The first experiment considered how the manipulation of prior level of task demand affected subsequent workload and performance. The second experiment examined the effects on performance and workload of increments in the level of task demand.</excerpt>

affiliations: Western Aerospace Labs, NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
title: Effects of Workload Preview on Task Scheduling During Simulated Instrument Flight
doc: <title>Effects of Workload Preview on Task Scheduling During Simulated Instrument Flight</title> <excerpt>Our study examined pilot scheduling behavior in the context of simulated instrument flight. Over the course of the flight, pilots flew along specified routes while scheduling and performing several flight-related secondary tasks. The first phase of flight was flown under low-workload conditions, whereas the second phase of flight was flown under high-workload conditions in the form of increased turbulence and a disorganized instrument layout.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aviation Research Laboratory, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
title: Flight Instruction: The Challenge From Situated Cognition
doc: <title>Flight Instruction: The Challenge From Situated Cognition</title> <excerpt>A primary claim from the field of situated cognition is that learning is ineffective if removed from the context in which the target skills must be deployed. This claim is inconsistent with many of the mainstream approaches to education and cognition. I describe what it means to be situated, and I outline the central issues raised in the literature on situated cognition and situated learning.</excerpt>

affiliations: Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX, United States; Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Depth and Collision Judgment Using Night Vision Goggles
doc: <title>Depth and Collision Judgment Using Night Vision Goggles</title> <excerpt>There is a concern about depth perception with night vision goggles (NVGs). We measured judgments involving depth perception in laboratory and field conditions. When participants judged absolute distance, or collision, in a laboratory, results indicated that objects can appear closer with NVGs than with unaided vision, and underestimations of distance were greater with smaller distances.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Otago, Dunedin, OTA, New Zealand
title: “Pressing On” Into Deteriorating Conditions: An Application of Behavioral Decision Theory to Pilot Decision Making
doc: <title>“Pressing On” Into Deteriorating Conditions: An Application of Behavioral Decision Theory to Pilot Decision Making</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. College of Engineering, Lubbock, TX, United States
title: Information Presentation for Expert Systems in Future Fighter Aircraft
doc: <title>Information Presentation for Expert Systems in Future Fighter Aircraft</title> <excerpt>Expert systems have been promoted as a means to reduce workload and provide improved decision support to pilots in advanced future aircraft. For these systems to be utilized effectively, a means of providing the recommendations of the system and information for assessing the quality of those recommendations must be provided in a manner that meets the stringent workload and time requirements of the cockpit. A research study was undertaken to determine interface guidelines for presenting information on expert-system recommendations in this context.</excerpt>

affiliations: ILLIANA Aviation Sciences Limited Areata, CA, United States; ILLIANA Aviation Sciences Limited, Mexico
title: Eye Accommodation: Use of Vernier Optometers in Behavioral Research
doc: <title>Eye Accommodation: Use of Vernier Optometers in Behavioral Research</title> <excerpt>The history of the invention and development of devices suitable for the measurement of eye accommodation in behavioral research settings is briefly reviewed. A series of small experiments involving a Micro Vernier Optometer that is “worn” on the head demonstrated the practicality of using the device in a variety of dynamic, real-world situations including flying an airplane simulator, driving an automobile, and'with certain constraints'typing at a video display terminal. Some surprising incidental findings are relevant to virtual imaging displays and to the Mandelbaum effect.</excerpt>

affiliations: Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
title: Effects of Low Blood Alcohol Levels On Pilots’ Prioritization of Tasks During a Radio Navigation Task
doc: <title>Effects of Low Blood Alcohol Levels On Pilots’ Prioritization of Tasks During a Radio Navigation Task</title> <excerpt>Eight pilots flew a specified cross-country route using radio navigation in a flight simulator with simulated air traffic control. Four of the pilots flew with a low blood alcohol level (BAL; mean BAL = 20.63 mg%). Pilots’ performance was compared in terms of flying performance, navigation, and radio communication.</excerpt>

affiliations: Federal Aviation Administration, Washington, D.C., United States; London Fire and Civil Defence Authority, London, United Kingdom
title: Predicting Aircraft Pilot-Training Success: A Meta-Analysis of Published Research
doc: <title>Predicting Aircraft Pilot-Training Success: A Meta-Analysis of Published Research</title> <excerpt>[No abstract available].</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, United States; Dynamics Research Corporation, Andover, MA, United States; Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, United States
title: Human Performance in Actuating Switches During Tracking
doc: <title>Human Performance in Actuating Switches During Tracking</title> <excerpt>The objectives of this study were to develop an engineering model of pilotage performance times in actuating switches and to test the feasibility of its use in task time-line analysis. A low-fidelity environment was simulated. Compensatory tracking was used to approximate the concurrent task of aircraft control corrections to turbulence during straight-level flight.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
title: Experimental Study of Electronically Based Instrument Approach Plates
doc: <title>Experimental Study of Electronically Based Instrument Approach Plates</title> <excerpt>Issues associated with the electronic presentation of instrument approach plates (IAPs) were investigated in a part-task simulation study using the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Aeronautical Systems Laboratory's Advanced Cockpit Simulator. Several electronic IAP chart formats were developed and evaluated. A decluttering system that allowed the pilots to selectively suppress various information groups in some of the prototype formats was also investigated.</excerpt>

affiliations: Organisation de l'aviation civile internationale, Montreal, QC, Canada
title: Crosscultural Perspectives in Human Factors Training: Lessons From the ICAO Human Factors Program
doc: <title>Crosscultural Perspectives in Human Factors Training: Lessons From the ICAO Human Factors Program</title> <excerpt>Since 1991, the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has conducted four human factors training seminars and supported numerous events on the same topic in virtually every region of the world. This has provided significant information on perceptions, needs, and obstacles regarding human factors training as expressed by operational personnel, regulators, and managers across the international aviation community. This article presents these different perspectives from a practitioner's point of view.</excerpt>

affiliations: Air Force Materiel Command, Dayton, OH, United States
title: Pilot-Candidate Selection Method: Sources of Validity
doc: <title>Pilot-Candidate Selection Method: Sources of Validity</title> <excerpt>Six hundred seventy-eight Air Force pilot training candidates were tested with a paper-and-pencil aptitude battery and computer-administered tests of psychomotor skills, information processing, and attitude toward risk. A self-report of flying experience was also collected.
