title: Postmortem fluid and tissue concentrations of THC, 11-OH-THC and THC-COOH
doc: <title>Postmortem fluid and tissue concentrations of THC, 11-OH-THC and THC-COOH</title> <excerpt>Marijuana is the most commonly abused illicit drug worldwide. Marijuana is used for its euphoric and relaxing properties. However, marijuana use has been shown to result in impaired memory, cognitive skills and psychomotor function.</excerpt>

affiliations: Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Cambridge, MA, United States; Department of Global Health and Social Medicine, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, United States; Graduate School of Public Health and Health Policy, The City University of New York, New York, NY, United States
title: If the framingham heart study did not invent the risk factor, who did?
doc: <title>If the framingham heart study did not invent the risk factor, who did?</title> <excerpt>Most historians, epidemiologists, and physicians credit the Framingham Heart Study for introducing the term “risk factor” to public health and medicine. Many add that the term came from life insurance companies. This familiar history is incorrect.</excerpt>

affiliations: Uniklinik Köln, Koln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; Fakultät 12, Technische Universität Dortmund, Dortmund, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; Institut für Notfallmedizin, Universität Witten/Herdecke, Witten, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany
title: Coping with complex medical emergency situations: Competent and successful decision-making, communication and leadership; Medizinisches Handeln in komplexen Notfallsituationen: Kompetent und erfolgreich entscheiden, kommunizieren und führen
doc: <title>Coping with complex medical emergency situations: Competent and successful decision-making, communication and leadership; Medizinisches Handeln in komplexen Notfallsituationen: Kompetent und erfolgreich entscheiden, kommunizieren und führen</title> <excerpt>Background: Stress is an integral part of the daily routine among healthcare workers in anesthesiology and emergency medicine. Objectives: This article describes negative stress effects in complex emergency situations and presents helpful tools for coping with them. Material and methods: Evaluation and discussion of selected medical and psychological publications and the inclusion of expert opinions are presented.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Exercise and Sport Science, University of Portsmouth, Portsmouth, Hampshire, United Kingdom
title: Habituation of the cold shock response may include a signifi cant perceptual component
doc: <title>Habituation of the cold shock response may include a signifi cant perceptual component</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Accidental immersion in cold water is a risk factor for many occupations. Habituation to cold-water immersion (CWI) is one practical means of reducing the cold shock response (CSR) on immersion. We investigated whether repeated thermoneutral water immersion (TWI) induced a perceptual habituation (ie, could lessen perceived threat and anxiety) and consequently reduce the CSR on subsequent CWI.</excerpt>

affiliations: Cumming School of Medicine, Calgary, AB, Canada; Office of Undergraduate Medical Education, Calgary, AB, Canada
title: The good and bad of group conformity: A call for a new programme of research in medical education
doc: <title>The good and bad of group conformity: A call for a new programme of research in medical education</title> <excerpt>Context: Given that a significant portion of medical education occurs in various social settings (small groups, large classes, clinical environments), it is critical to examine how group members interact. One type of influence on these interactions is conformity, whereby an individual changes his or her own behaviour to match incorrect responses of others in a group. Conformity to peer pressure has been replicated in experimental research conducted in many countries over the last 60 years.</excerpt>

affiliations: College of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Exeter, Exeter, Devon, United Kingdom
title: Evaluating stress as a challenge is associated with superior attentional control and motor skill performance: Testing the predictions of the biopsychosocial model of challenge and threat
doc: <title>Evaluating stress as a challenge is associated with superior attentional control and motor skill performance: Testing the predictions of the biopsychosocial model of challenge and threat</title> <excerpt>The biopsychosocial model of challenge and threat (Blascovich, 2008) suggests that individuals who evaluate a performance situation as a challenge will perform better than those who evaluate it as a threat. However, limited research has examined (a) the influence of challenge and threat evaluations on learned motor performance under pressure and (b) the attentional processes by which this effect occurs. In the present study 52 novices performed a motor task (laparoscopic surgery), for which optimal visual attentional control has been established.</excerpt>

affiliations: University of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Universities Space Research Association, Columbia, MD, United States
title: Outcome measure to assess head-down bed rest subject performance
doc: <title>Outcome measure to assess head-down bed rest subject performance</title> <excerpt>Background: The purpose of the present study was to develop an objective outcome measure to assess the performance of head-down bed rest subjects. The rationale behind the development was that the current outcome measure is subjective and dependent upon how much the clinical psychologist knows about subject behaviors during the study to rate them accurately. Methods: The behaviorally anchored rating scales (BARS) were developed through the use of the critical incident technique, along with traditional BARS development procedures, and the use of focus groups.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (DLR), Koln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; State Scientific Center of Russian Federation, Institute for Biomedical Problems, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
title: De-individualized psychophysiological strain assessment during a flight simulation test-Validation of a space methodology
doc: <title>De-individualized psychophysiological strain assessment during a flight simulation test-Validation of a space methodology</title> <excerpt>For the evaluation of an operator's skill reliability indicators of work quality as well as of psychophysiological states during the work have to be considered. The herein presented methodology and measurement equipment were developed and tested in numerous terrestrial and space experiments using a simulation of a spacecraft docking on a space station. However, in this study the method was applied to a comparable terrestrial task-the flight simulator test (FST) used in the DLR selection procedure for ab initio pilot applicants for passenger airlines.</excerpt>

affiliations: Russian Medical Academy of Postgraduate Education, Federal Agency for Health Care and Social Development, Krasnoyarsk, Krasnoyarsk, Russian Federation
title: Prognostic value of studying personality traits of civil aviation pilots
doc: <title>Prognostic value of studying personality traits of civil aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>A clinical and psychological examination of civil aviation pilots, including ones with a history of attempted suicide, and an in-depth study of the personality qualities of the pilots by means of a modified standardized multifactor personality study and a portrait choice method based on a modification of Szondi's test for eight drives were performed. The analysis of psychological features in pilots with a history of attempted suicide showed a neurotic type of maladaptation formed on the basis of the domination of hyposthenic traits in the personality structure. Neurotic behavior, pessimism, increased anxiety, and introversion that had become acute under the specific social and occupational conditions transformed into depressive signs and avoidance of social problems.</excerpt>

affiliations: Division of Aerospace Psychology, Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (DLR), Koln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; State Scientific Center of Russian Federation, Institute for Biomedical Problems, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
title: Performance assessment in a flight simulator test-Validation of a space psychology methodology
doc: <title>Performance assessment in a flight simulator test-Validation of a space psychology methodology</title> <excerpt>The objective assessment of operator performance in hand controlled docking of a spacecraft on a space station has 30 years of tradition and is well established. In the last years the performance assessment was successfully combined with a psycho-physiological approach for the objective assessment of the levels of physiological arousal and psychological load. These methods are based on statistical reference data.</excerpt>

affiliations: Naval Air Station, Naval Aerospace Medicine Institute, Pensacola, FL, United States; Naval Air Station, Naval Aerospace Medicine Institute, Pensacola, FL, United States
title: Alcohol screening instruments and psychiatric evaluation outcomes in military aviation personnel
doc: <title>Alcohol screening instruments and psychiatric evaluation outcomes in military aviation personnel</title> <excerpt>Introduction: Alcohol-related disorders are the most prevalent psychiatric conditions in the aviation population. Efforts to effectively screen aviators for these disorders are continually sought, as under-diagnosis may negatively impact aviation safety. This study evaluates screening tools that have been validated in non-aviators in terms of their utility for aviator patients.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Psychology, Universität Graz, Graz, Styria, Austria
title: Evaluation of a spatial disorientation simulator training for jet pilots
doc: <title>Evaluation of a spatial disorientation simulator training for jet pilots</title> <excerpt>To evaluate the efficiency of a disorientation-recovery program using the Airfox DISO flight simulator (Disorientation Trainer, AMST Systemtechnik GmbH, Austria), 26 jet pilots were tested. The pilots were randomly allocated to 1 of 3 groups: Training, Awareness, or Control group. The training for the Training group included demonstration trials of the disorientation phenomena Gyro Spin, Leans, Dark Take-off, Expectation Error, Black Hole Approach, and False Horizon (awareness phase) and additional reorientation exercises (training phase).</excerpt>

affiliations: Idaho National Laboratory, Idaho Falls, ID, United States; Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Washington, D.C., DC, United States
title: The use of empirical data sources in HRA
doc: <title>The use of empirical data sources in HRA</title> <excerpt>This paper presents a review of available information related to human performance to support Human Reliability Analysis (HRA) performed for nuclear power plants (NPPs). A number of data sources are identified as potentially useful. These include NPP licensee event reports, augmented inspection team reports, operator requalification data, results from the literature in experimental psychology, and the Aviation Safety Reporting System.</excerpt>

title: Psychiatric considerations in military aerospace medicine
doc: <title>Psychiatric considerations in military aerospace medicine</title> <excerpt>Military aerospace medicine requires a psychiatric selection and certification process that determines not only the absence of significant mental disorders, but also the presence of positive qualities in the realms of motivation, ability and stability: not all normal people are fit to fly. Other issues of aerospace psychiatry involve maintenance of mental resilience and hardiness during a flying career, aeromedical decisions about when to remove from flight duties and when to return, criteria for waivers for psychiatric conditions, use of medications for treatment of psychiatric symptoms, questions of substance abuse, and research in such areas as genetics. This report reviews the basis for military aerospace psychiatry, primarily as practiced in the United States Air Force (USAF), and presents some of its underlying principles as they apply to clinical situations..</excerpt>

affiliations: Abt. Luft-und Raumfahrtpsychologie, Institut für Luft- und Raumfahrtmedizin, Hamburg, Germany
title: Psychological aspects of human spaceflight: effects on human cognitive, psychomotor, and attentional performance
doc: <title>Psychological aspects of human spaceflight: effects on human cognitive, psychomotor, and attentional performance</title> <excerpt>Since the first human spaceflight into orbit, the space environment has become one of the most extreme working environments for humans. Staying and working in a space habitat is connected with exposure to a lot of different stressors all of which may entail detrimental effects on human performance and psychological well-being of astronauts. However, the psychological impact of the extreme environmental conditions in space and particularly its impact on mental performance of astronauts has only recently become an object of systematic research.</excerpt>

affiliations: Aerospace Medicine Residency Program, Nav. Aerosp. and Oper. Med. Inst., Pensacola, FL, United States; Dept. of Neurol. and Int. Medicine, Nav. Aerosp. and Oper. Med. title: Panic with a twist: An unusual presentation of combined psychiatric and neurologic symptoms in a tactical jet aviator
doc: <title>Panic with a twist: An unusual presentation of combined psychiatric and neurologic symptoms in a tactical jet aviator</title> <excerpt>A 28-yr-old Naval F-14 aviator presented with complaints of flight- related anxiety occurring intermittently over an 18-mo period. Symptoms included sensation of strangeness, concern over the welfare of his radar intercept officer, flushing, nausea, and intense need to immediately land the aircraft. He also described a 6-mo history of episodes wherein he would see 'shooting stars' in the periphery of his vision, accompanied by dizziness and disorientation.</excerpt>

title: The aggressive ward visitor: a critical incident analysis.
doc: <title>The aggressive ward visitor: a critical incident analysis.</title> <excerpt>Since its conception by the aviation psychologist Flanagan the critical incident technique has been used in nursing studies to investigate many aspects of nursing practice. While its use as a nursing research tool and a classroom teaching aid have been discussed, little has been written on the use of the technique for individual reflection for those doing post-registration courses. In this paper, the author discusses her personal reflections following a critical incident and the need for the technique to be refined.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, SA, Australia
title: Crisis management - Validation of an algorithm by analysis of 2000 incident reports
doc: <title>Crisis management - Validation of an algorithm by analysis of 2000 incident reports</title> <excerpt>Anaesthetists are called upon to manage complex life-threatening crises at a moment's notice. As there is evidence that this may require cognitive tasking beyond the information-processing capacity of the human brain, it was decided to try and develop a generic crisis management algorithm analogous to the 'Phase I' immediate response routine used by airline pilots. Such an algorithm, based on the mnemonic 'COVER ABCD, A SWIFT CHECK', was developed and refined over 3 meetings, each attended by 60-100 anaesthetists and aviation psychologists.</excerpt>

affiliations: Service de Sante, Base Aeronavale, France
title: Evaluation of zolpidem on alertness and psychomotor abilities among aviation ground personnel and pilots
doc: <title>Evaluation of zolpidem on alertness and psychomotor abilities among aviation ground personnel and pilots</title> <excerpt>The use of hypnotics to optimize rest periods during sustained operations could be of help to military personnel. Zolpidem, an imidazopyridine hypnotic, was evaluated for its residual effects on daytime wakefulness in 12 subjects belonging to ground air force personnel and 12 navy fighter pilots. In this controlled double blind crossover study, each subject randomly received zolpidem 10mg, flunitrazepam 1mg or placebo, in three separate sessions, 1 week apart at 10 p.m.</excerpt>

affiliations: Department of Aviation Psychiatry, Naval Operational Medicine Institute, Pensacola, FL, United States
title: Brief reactive psychosis in naval aviation
doc: <title>Brief reactive psychosis in naval aviation</title> <excerpt>Five naval aviation personnel diagnosed with brief reactive psychosis (BRP) have appeared before the Special Board of Flight Surgeons (SBFS) at the Naval Aerospace Medical Institute (NAMI). These cases demonstrate the challenges in diagnosis and disposition that face the clinical aeromedical specialist in evaluating the aviator who develops psychiatric symptoms. We discuss the aeromedical factors that must be considered when contemplating returning aviators with psychiatric diagnoses to flying duties.</excerpt>

title: The psychiatrist's role in aerospace operations
doc: <title>The psychiatrist's role in aerospace operations</title> <excerpt>This paper presents two unique aspects of aerospace psychiatry: the influence of the specialized stressors and occupational requirements of an aviation career and the ambiguous role of the aerospace psychiatrist. Aerospace psychiatrists have multiple, sometimes conflicting, responsibilities to the organization and society (the social control task) and to the individual aviator (the humanistic and medical tasks). In the two case reports below the authors describe airmen who had vasovagal syncope and how the psychiatrist intervened and resolved these conflicting tasks..</excerpt>

title: Innovations in training: The New Aviation Scientist--Psychologist and Engineer
doc: <title>Innovations in training: The New Aviation Scientist--Psychologist and Engineer</title> <excerpt>Notes that meaningful research in applied experimental psychology is often conducted as an interdisciplinary effort. This approach is especially prevalent in aviation because particular consideration must be given to human capabilities and limitations in the aircraft system design process. This article describes the Aviation Research Laboratory at the Institute of Aviation of the University of Illinois, which provides a unique environment for graduate training in aviation research.</excerpt>

title: Differentiating characteristics of a group of students having psychological problems
doc: <title>Differentiating characteristics of a group of students having psychological problems</title> <excerpt>2 groups of Navy and Marine trainees who had psychological problems were contrasted with 2 groups of normal trainees on 16 variables. Critical ratio statistic was used for comparisons involving means and chi square was employed for comparisons involving a number of Ss. Significant differences between psychological problems groups are corresponding normal groups were obtained for 6 of the variables.</excerpt>

title: The development of a job sample trouble-shooting performance examination
doc: <title>The development of a job sample trouble-shooting performance examination</title> <excerpt>A four-part job sample trouble-shooting performance test designed to measure critical abilities needed to trouble-shoot aircraft electrical apparatus is described. The subtests were not highly intercorrelated, and they were found to discriminate moderately well (in mean score) between classes of Naval aviation electricians. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).</excerpt>

title: Psychological Research in Aviation in Italy, France, England, and the American Expeditionary Forces
doc: <title>Psychological Research in Aviation in Italy, France, England, and the American Expeditionary Forces</title> <excerpt>Psychology well needs to thank its stars that the World War came, and that it brought demands, situations, problems, apparatus, contacts of national and international scope, herds of men gathered together, and dynamic interest in technical and practical pursuits of a psychological nature. Reference is here being made most specifically to the reaction-time experiment for one, salvaged by the workers on aviation problems. And new experiments with new techniques were fashioned and new combinations of old techniques were instituted.</excerpt>
